title: JGAurora A5 Infrared Autobed Level modification
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
JG Aurora Infrared sensor upgrade

Version 1.3 12th Feb 2018

15th Feb 2018 - Updated to V2 sensor holder. Now includes LED mount and slotted holes
12th Feb 2018 - Updated firmware (uploaded the wrong version)
22nd Jan 2018 - Updated firmware to the latest release, updated to 25 point bed level
10th Jan 2018 - Updated firmware to the latest release

WARNING WARNING

MAKE SURE YOU DOUBLE CHECK YOUR CONNECTIONS
POSITIVE to POSITIVE
NEGATIVE to NEGATIVE
SIGNAL to SIGNAL

The connections are written on the boards.. so it's easy to check.

WARNING WARNING

Description
Autobed level addition to the JG Aurora A5 3D printer.

Items you will require
Infrared sensor - https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/
3 wire servo extension lead (2 x 1m in length)

Files included
Mount STL
Front cover

To do this modification you will need to update the main board's firmware. You will need to update using the Arduino IDE software.
There are plenty of youtube videos showing you how to do this, just search for update marlin via arduino ide.

You will need to open your machine up and feed the 3 wire connector around the machine. The sensor uses the Z minimum endstop connector, so just unplug the current one.

The current z endstop needs to be removed. Just unscrew it from the side frame and hide it below. You can always go back then if needed.

I've already configured the firmware to use this sensor, so you will only need to flash it. I have enabled the eeprom on the board, so you can save
bed levels.. but I would level at the start of every print just to be safe.

To level, you will need to add some gcode lines to your start gcode script. There is normally a tab / section in your software.. the lines you need to add are,

Add these AFTER the G28 (Home) command.

M851 Z-1.0 ; Z Offset
M500 ; Save to Eeprom
G28 ; Home
G29 ; Level bed
etc...

The Z offset can be set above. Z-1.0 = 1mm.. so if you want to lower the head then you would do..
M851 Z-1.2 ; Z Offset
This would then be 0.2mm closer than before.

You don't need to change the TFT firmware, you won't get any benefit from it as it doesn't support Z offset setting

The cover, just slides down onto the mount :-) it didn't look very nice without it.

Printer:

JGAurora A5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%
Designed in Inventor

title: Prusa I3 Pro B Frame brace with front plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Frame Brace with Front plate.
Attention: You got about 5mm less build volume in the y axis, make sure to add this to your firmware.

I´ve also made it compatible with the anet a8 y belt tensioner because i think it looks nice :)
The belt tensioner isn´t mine, ive only remixed the belt holder/tensioner. The bolt and plate is from Audiogod.
The CTC Prusa I3 Pro B comes with a belt tensioner that uses 8mm ball bearings. The belt tensioner and the idler pulley are compatible with those parts.
Watch out! your printer should be properly calibrated before you print this thing. My printer actually printed it 1.5% smaller than it needed to be, making it unusable because it bends the y-axis rods.

UPDATE: I have improved the GT2 idler pulley, belt now stays where it should be, must be printed with supports now.

UPDATE: M4 version of the idler pulley and belt tensioner has been added. Use a 4mm drill to drill out the holes if your printer makes them too small. Don´t forget that either the M4 screw or the Idler pulley should be able to rotate freely. The screw shouldn´t be larger than 34mm. I recommend using a 30mm M4 screw.

title: x & y endstop bracket for Alunar 506. Fixes inaccurate "auto home".

description.text:
Just assembled the Alunar 506, one of the many budget Prusa clones. When I first reverted to the home location, it was not even near the bed. It was about 10mm off of where it should be in both directions.

These mounts are exactly like the factory ones, except the switch mounting holes have been shifted 10mm from the original locations. The auto home location now sits 6.3mm past the edge in the X direction and 10.2mm past the edge in the Y direction (to compensate for the leveling screw). Quick and easy permanent fix.

Printer:

Alunar 506

No

No

Notes:

I added a little ledge where the nut sits on the Y mount so it doesn't fall through when installing.

This is a drilling template for pinewood derby car blocks. Drilling using a #44 bit is better than using the standard cut slots, which make alignment of the wheels difficult to make and maintain. With this template, you don't have to worry about making mistakes in where the holes are drilled.

There are holes for the standard positions, as well as for an extended wheelbase. Just insert the block, drill and remove.

On my print the block fits pretty snugly. Depending on your printer you may need to sand the inside a little.

The v2 file has wider sides around the holes, which can help with drilling straight.

title: Simplify3D Prusa i3 MK3 Bed File

description.text:
Update 01/29/18: Not critical--prusai3mk3-v3.stl added. Or download the last file, prusai3mk3.stl, that is 75KB. prusai3mk3-v2.stl had the origin in the wrong place. If you use the last file instead of v3, you will not need to rename anything. The last two files are identical except in name. Just delete the older file in ...\AppData\Local\Simplify3D\S3D-Software. Won't make much difference in S3D if you don't do this.

NOTE: I noticed that the first file, prusai3mk3.stl, was unnecessarily large: 4MB. I have put another file in the downloads, prusai3mk3-v2.stl. It's only 78.5KB. Download it rename it to prusai3mk3.stl, and overwrite or delete the older file in you AppData folder. Probably won't make much difference if you don't do this.

This is a bed shape model file for the Prusa i3 MK3 for use in Simplify 3d.

You have to export your Prusa i3 MK3.fff file. (probably a little different filename)
Export the .fff file from the S3D File menu to, "C:\Users\YOUR_USER_NAME\AppData \Local\Simplify3D\S3D-Software"
Download the .stl file here, prusai3mk3.stl, and save it in the same folder you just saved the .fff to.
Edit the . fff file with a text editor. Notepad++ (best) or Wordpad will work.
Find the line: --printerModelsOverride/----printerModelsOverride--
Edit the line to read: --printerModelsOverride--prusai3mk3.stl--/printerModelsOverride--
(sorry folks, the programmers of this site do not handle quote marks or greater than less than symbols properly, so the double minus signs are greater than less than symbols in the two lines above)
Save the modified .fff file.
Run S3D.
Delete your Prusa i3 MK3.fff ( or whatever the name is) from the Edit Process window or you will end up with duplicates. This is optional but recommended.
From the File menu, import the edited .fff file.

title: DIY Close Loop Control Filament Dryer

description.text:
When printing with materials such as Nylon, PETG, or Ninjaflex, one can find that some of these filaments can be hygroscopic (absorbs water.. in this case, from the atmosphere). Once water is absorbed into filament, the print quality and ease of printing can plummet and make for some pretty miserable prints.

One way to dry filament is to put it in an oven. This is great if you want to spend the money on a food dehydrator or your spouse doesn't mind you putting plastic into your nice new kitchen oven. However, one other way it to use a chamber and a light bulb. This method works well but different materials can require different temperatures due to glass transition temperature (the point where plastic begins to soften).

By using arduino, we can build a closed loop control drying box that works similar to your oven.

Set your max temperature allowed, your amount of temperature tolerance, the number of hours you'd like to dry and you're good to go. The controller heats the chamber up to your max set temp, turns the light off until the chamber hits the Max temp - tolerance then turns the light back on again to continue cycling.

After the specified number of hours, the controller switches to "Humidity Hold mode". The user inputs a maximum percentage humidity to hold in the chamber and the controller only turns the light on long enough to keep the humidity below that percentage. It's a nice energy saver mode if you're not going to get to your newly-dried filament right away and bag it up.

Through our testing, I've been able to dry nylon that was submerged in water for a few days and get perfect prints again.

You can see the results of the dryer in my 3 part Youtube series here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nOc5qVhb3rc Part 1
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NQ3DC4GpA3w Part 2
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ehsgazhJ17U Part 3

The instructions will be put on instructables soon, but for now here is a link to the word document that takes you step by step through the entire assembly process; pictures included.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/153k5ccl8jt00oq/DIY%20Closed%20Loop%20Controlled%20Filament%20Dryer%20V2.doc?dl=0

If you run into any issues of have any questions, don't hesitate to contact me.

It's a really fun project and I hope a few of you take the time to give it a shot!

The entire assembly instructions document can be found at the following link: https://www.dropbox.com/s/153k5ccl8jt00oq/DIY%20Closed%20Loop%20Controlled%20Filament%20Dryer%20V2.doc?dl=0

The document includes step by step directions and pictures on how to build your own filament dryer.

If you find any errors in wording, please let me know so I can update it quickly. I've had one other person successfully build a dryer so things should be pretty clear.

title: Snake Cube Puzzle Large 4x4 or Small 3x3

description.text:
A while ago I saw a snake puzzle which was basically a chain of square wooden blocks, which when twisted and bent correctly, resulted in a perfect 3x3x3 cube.

I decided to research and create the next level up, which is a 4x4x4 cube from a 64 block snake !

This Thing needs to be printed twice, ideally in opposing colours. then assembling with a long string or better still is elastic cord.

UPDATE: I've just realised that printing this thing ONCE gives you the right number of cubes to make the 3x3 cube so I've included info for that one too now.

The end pieces are designed so that a knot can be tied in the end of the string then the cap glued on to completely hide the knot.

Once you have all the cubes printed - there will be a few spares left over just in case you have a faulty one, or you lose one etc.

if you print it at the size drawn, the individual cubes will be 15mm and you'll need about 1 metre of string or elastic cord. Feel free to enlarge or reduce the size as you wish - just ensure both colours are printed exactly the same size!.

To thread the cubes, thread an end piece and knot it into the end cap.
then with alternating colours assemble it as follows - they're arranged in groups of three just to make it easier to see and keep track when you're threading them. and there are a couple of pictures so you can check your progress. - you'll be starting at the right hand side of the picture.

( S = straight through block C= Corner hole block )

Large - 4x4 cube

CSS CCC
CCC CCC
CSC CSS
CCC CSS
CSC CCC
CCS CSC
CCC CCC
CCS CCS
CCS CCS
SCC CSC
CS

Small - 3x3 Cube

SCS CSC
SCC CCS
CSC CCS
CCS CCCS

And then the other last end piece making sure the string/elastic is tight enough when you knot it off.

Wanhao i3

Infill:

10%

Notes:

ignore the times on the printer - at standard size expect it to take 18 hours to print each colour.
simply thread an elastic cord all the way through all the blocks and pull it tight.

I designed this as a Z-Axis anti-vibration brace for my FLSUN Prusa i3. The little clips click into the 6mm channel on 20X20mm extruded aluminum frame pieces. There is a hole for a 4-4.5mm bolt to lock the clips in place.
Vibration is (at least empirically) much better on the side with the brace installed as the other one was printing. (Edit - Both in now, much improved Z-vibes)
Sure, a heavier brace could be designed, but I wanted to showcase a bit and look cool. This is actually pretty stiff, and it's vibration we're eliminating, not holding huge mass anyway.

Printed in ABS but PLA should/might work too. Fits on a 200X200mm glass bed with rounded corners, but not by much, so maybe keep the skirt close in...

Took 6 hours on my rig, printing ~63mm/s.

description.text:
We had a 1990's air hockey table (I believe from Sears) that had injection molded ABS corners. The repeated impact of the puck on the ~4mm thick ABS walls eventually cracked the ABS, rendering the corners pretty much terrible. They got bad enough that the puck would get stuck in the corner.

I recently got a pair of calipers and designed a replacement. I've printed one in PLA, and it fit perfectly and functions fantastically. This design includes honeycomb infill behind the impact wall, which is now considerably thicker than 4mm as well.

  • Horizontal Shells

  • Infill: 10% honeycomb.
  • Top/Bottom fill pattern: Hilbert Curve

  • Combine infill every 3 layers.

    • Interface Layers: 2

    • Interface loops: No
A simple adapter to hold bigger non-XYZ filament spool in place of smaller original spools.

A classic puzzle Tower of Hanoi slightly redesigned to be accessible to those clumsy small 3D printed robot arms or little human. A few design considerations:

  • Gear shaped handle for robot gripper
  • Stacking disks instead of a rod for easy handling
  • Cone like socket to make moving pieces easier

If you are not familiar with the puzzle here is the rules from wikipedia:

The puzzle starts with the disks in a neat stack in ascending order of size on one rod, the smallest at the top, thus making a conical shape.

The objective of the puzzle is to move the entire stack to another rod, obeying the following simple rules:

  • Only one disk can be moved at a time.
  • Each move consists of taking the upper disk from one of the stacks and placing it on top of another stack.
  • No disk may be placed on top of a smaller disk.

remixed_from.author: TazerReloaded
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Universal Toolhead Mount / QuickSwap

title: Quick Swap Mounting System for Anet A8 3D Printers

description.text:
Quick Swap Mounting System for Anet A8/Prusia Printers

This is something that was inspired by TazerReloaded's dremel tool mount. I was looking at it and several other tool mounts and wondered how nice it would be if they all used the same system. So I did some modification to them and made the main things available that are most commonly used with this printer. It works with the standard Direct Direct Stock metal bracket if you cut 2 3mm square notches close to the bottom back edge. Included are the following:

  • 1 - Main Mounting Bracket - This will replace your main tool mount. Extra options can be mounted on the back (holes exist for screws for the X-axis belt and any x-axis belt holder you can find around here)
  • 2 - Bowden Head Mount Plate - For any standard E3D Bowden Head (Extruder mount coming)
  • 3 - Bowden Head Clamp - To secure the E3D head to the mounting plate (duh)
  • 4 - Bowden Head Fan Duct - Mount the fan on the top square hole and the fan duct on the bottom (two screws will hold it in place nicely).
  • 5 - Laser Mounting Plate - For a cheap laser... got mine here

    https://goo.gl/obFmFD

  • 6 - Dremel Wand Mount Plate - Want to turn your printer into a CNC machine? This mount will hold the Dremel Wand attachment for CNC routing on your printer!
  • 7 - Dremel Wand Clamp - Of course you have to clamp it tightly or it won't hold still and flop around uselessly!
  • 8 - Blank Mounting Plate - I added this in for you to add your own mount for whatever you can dream of... If I don't have a mount for your specific needs, just slap it onto this little bad boy and you're good to go!
  • 9 - Pen/Knife Mounting Plate - Here's a nifty little plate that you can clamp a pen, pencil, brush, or X-atco knife to! Might come in handy! It'll hold any round shafted object up to 15mm, just use a screw in each of the holes to hold it firmly.

I've seen other universal mounts that over complicate things dramatically (even going so far as to make you do all the wiring to the mounting bracket) but honestly, this is a simple idea, it's quick change, can print multiple copies to have an extra ready in case something goes wrong with one. Really makes swapping out different tools easy! Give it a try and lemme know what you think! Here's a video of how quick it is to swap out the tool heads... https://youtu.be/nASWiiNW6_k


LATEST UPDATES:
1-18-18
  • I created a new Pen holding plate for Plotting... can also be used to hold an X-Acto knife!

1-16-18:

  • Added some holes to side of mounting bracket to make it easier to add accessories like sensors, fans, etc.
  • Fixed the mounting holes for fan duct on bowden mount, they were too low.
  • added locking pin behind plate to make plate more rigid in the bracket so it doesn't move up and down while printing.
  • Made Dremel Flex Shaft Mount Plate beefier
  • Made mounting plate beefier so it doesn't flex at all.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

15-20%

Notes:

Most items do not need supports and are oriented the way they should be printed. The Laser Plate and the Bowden Plate should have supports turned on.

Some items will require screws. The clamps that hold the Bowden head, fan duct, Pen, and the Dremel will require some small screws to hold them in place. I just used spares from my screw jar so don't really have exact types of screws, but I did include areas for nuts in several areas. Most screws will self tap into the plastic for a firm hold however.

comments.text: You mean the X-Axis belt... it's easy... there are several options... 1) You can use the screws that came stock with the printer and screw them into the holes in the back of the mounting plate, then attach the belts to the screws (just like the stock mounting board) or 2) There are tons of x-axis belt tensionors on here that will fit perfectly with no modifiction since the holes are in the exact same position that the stock mounting carriage is in.  If it works for the stock mounting carriage, it will work with this, no problem!

Lots of good stuff to play with.  If anyone comes up with any new kind of plates for different tools, please let me know and I'll add it into the set for everyone to use!

title: Double Swivelling Towel Bar for the bathroom

description.text:
Wall mounted double swivelling towel bar for the bathroom

Towel bar is mounted to the wall with two 4 mm screws for a solid connection.
The towel bars are made of a piece of 10 mm aluminum tubing. Both bars are held by a 6 mm bolt and nut. The base is designed to hold a bolt with allen head. The underside is cut out for the nut to be held in place.
The end of the tubes is capped in the front a 3D printed plug which is also part of the design.
(PLEASE NOTE: As shown in the pictures, ALWAYS use flat-headed screws when attaching anything that is 3D printed. Ordinary screws with conical heads can easily split your 3D print).

The towel bar as shown in the pictures was printed in red PETG to match the red wall mounted cup holder.

Model was designed in OpenSCAD.

Printer:

Creatbot DE Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

120 micron

Infill:

45%

Notes:

To make sure the parts have a decent strength, print with at least 3 shells and 40% infill.

Print in any material you like.
The red part shown was printed in PETG for its higher than PLA temperature resistance.
But could be just as well printed in PLA, ABS, NGEN, XT or any other material.

Supports are not really necessary, but you might use some to get the horizontally oriented holes a little nicer, depending on your printer and/or slicer capabilities.

Step 1: Print the part step 2: You need an aluminum tube Step 3: if you have finished the tube, take a 6mm drill and see if he goes through the pipe clean Step 4: Push the rubber sealing ring over the pipe into the notch. check if the BB's are stopped .. but not too tight! Step 5: - put it all together, the seal is on the side of the vector magazine. (for the correct positioning of the tube) - insert the vector magazine into the adapter. - place the adapter with the vector magazine in the speedloader (Odin Innovations M12 Sidewinder). -Draw off the speedloader. - Drop 2 drops of two-component epoxy in the window on the side. - Put everything together and let it dry.

Its open underneath to stack (they actually lock!) and semi interlocking along the sides.

1/9/18 - As I learn Blender I'm getting better at it, so all three tiles are new with uniform spacing, better faces and locking feet in the center of the multiple tiles. Hopefully the slightly smaller outside profile allows multiple singles to be fit on top of a combined tile.

1/9/18 - Updated again, after the prototype, just a small adjustment on the spacing between tiles on the multiples and some face cleanup.

1/9/18 (late) - there was a problem with the multiples again but I'm hoping these will be the last uploads for these two problem children.

1/11/18 - Final

title: Delta 3D Printer Heated Glass Bed with levelers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For a Kossel 2020 Delta and other similar Delta 3D printers:

  • Adds a glass bed for more convenient printing
  • Adds 6 point manual bed leveling.
  • Eliminates the need for auto bed leveling inductor which reduces print head weight.
  • Allows one-time bed leveling, although minor adjustments can be made even during printing.
  • Includes hot end mount without inductor holder and captive hex nuts for easier mounting
  • Allows print head calibration without flashing the firmware
  • includes carriage with adjusting screw for easier calibration

Requires making a new bed mounting board from MDF or other suitable material. The aluminum heated bed gets drilled and tapped so that mounting screws can be attached to the bottom of the bed. This eliminates the screw heads from the top of the bed, allowing a borosilicate glass plate to be used on top of the aluminum plate. Springs are used in conjunction with printed thumbwheels to provide 6 leveling points for the bed for making fine adjustments even during printing.

Printer:

Kossel 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

25%

Notes:

These print settings are not critical. There are just two parts to print for the bed mounting, a thumbwheel and a spacer. You will need 6 of each. Print the parts before disassembling your printer.

I have included a modified hot end mount that does not have the holder for the auto leveling inductor. It features captive hex nuts that makes mounting and removing the hot end much easier.

I have also included a modified carriage that features an adjusting screw for easier calibration.

See my improved sliders and carriages for delta printers here

TOOLS REQUIRED
  • jig saw, table saw, sliding miter saw or other means of cutting the MDF.
  • drill press.
  • 3.5 mm drill bit
  • 2.5 mm drill bit (optional)
  • 4 mm drill bit
  • 4 mm tap
  • 3 mm tap (optional)
HARDWARE REQUIRED
  • 1/2" thick MDF large enough to cover the base of the printer
  • M4 x 45 mm pan head screws (6)
  • M4 hex nuts (6)
  • M4 hex keeper nuts (6) or M4 hex nuts and lock washers (6 each)
  • Compression spring - 1 1/8 x 1/4 x .035 (6) - Ace Hardware #145
  • M3 x 20 mm pan head screws (6)
  • M3 twist lock T-nuts (6)
  • M3 washers (6)
  • Round Borosilicate Glass - 220 mm diameter x 3 mm thick
  • 3/4" Binder Clips (3)
MAKE THE BASE BOARD

Place the printer on top of the MDF board and trace the outline of the triangle. Don't worry too much about the corners as these will get cut off. Draw guide lines 10 mm inside the traced line for the mounting screws. Cut out the triangle using the saw of your choice. Cut off the corners of the triangle so that the board fits the base of your printer without interfering with the belts.

DRILL THE MOUNTING HOLES FOR THE HEATED BED

Center the aluminum heated bed on the triangle and carefully mark the 6 mounting holes. A self-centering vix bit is particularly useful. If you have marked accurately, you can drill the holes using a 4 mm bit. If your marking is inaccurate, it is okay to drill these holes slightly oversized, but you may need an additional washer on the underside of the board during assembly.

DRILL THE MOUNTING HOLES FOR THE BASE BOARD

Using the 10 mm guide line, drill 2 holes on each edge for mounting the board on the 2020 rails. Spacing is not critical here, approximately 1 inch from the end is what I used. I drilled these to 3.5 mm to give some additional tolerance when mounting.

DRILL THE MOUNTING HOLES FOR THE CONTROLLER BOARD AND HEATED BED WIRING

Mark and drill holes for mounting the controller boards. I drilled 2.5mm holes and tapped them to 3 mm. You could also drill them to 3mm and use a nut. Another option is to mount the controller board using nylon zip ties. This requires 2 small holes at each mounting point to loop the zip tie through.

Drill a larger hole at the point that you want to bring down your heated bed wiring.

You can paint the MDF board with shellac based primer

The base board with all the holes drilled. The large hole is for the wires DRILL AND TAP THE HOLES IN THE ALUMINUM HEATED PLATE

Using a drill press to keep the holes vertical, enlarge the existing holes to 3.5mm. Then cut threads in the holes using a 4mm tap.

The aluminum heated bed is drilled and tapped to accept M4 screws ASSEMBLE THE BED MOUNTING HARDWARE

The hardware is installed in the order of the photo below. The M4 x 45mm screw and spring are inserted first from below the base board. If the spring is sliding into your oversized mounting hole, use an M4 washer between the board and the spring. Above the board, add the spacer, the thumbwheel with the hex head opening facing up and the hex nut. Lastly add the keeper nut or hex nut and lock washer. Do this for each of the 6 mounting holes.

The bed mounting hardware in the order of assembly The adjustable bed mounting assembly MOUNT THE CONTROLLER BOARD

Attach the controller board to the bottom of the base board.

The mounted controller board MOUNT THE HEATED BED TO THE BASE BOARD

After routing the heater and thermistor wires through the large wiring hole, place the aluminum plate on top of the mounting hardware so that the screws line up with the mounting holes. Thread the screws into the aluminum plate until the screws are flush with or just below the top surface of the plate. Tighten the keeper nuts (or lock washer and hex nut) against the bottom of the aluminum plate to lock the screws to the plate. This will keep the screws from turning when adjusting the thumb screws.

Mounting screws locked to the aluminum plate with the keeper nuts. MOUNT THE BASE BOARD ONTO THE PRINTER

Using the M3 x 20 mm screws and the M3 twist lock nuts, mount the base board onto the printer's rails. Use a washer to keep the screw heads from sliding into the oversized holes and to keep the 20mm screws from bottoming out in the rails. It takes some determination to get all 6 twist lock nuts lined up and secured. If necessary, drill the holes slightly larger.

The M3 twist lock nuts are 10mm from the edge so that they are centered on the 20mm rails. ATTACH THE GLASS TO THE PRINT BED

Use 3 or 4 3/4" binder clips to hold the glass onto the print bed. A mist of hair spray on the glass will help the prints adhere better. Adjust the thumbwheels so that none of them are loose. The thumb wheels can be used to make minor leveling adjustments to the print bed, even during printing. Be careful to make small adjustments as it is possible to actually bend the aluminum plate

The finished modification.

Design Goals & Motivation

Bed leveling is a particular challenge on a delta printer. I wanted to find an alternative to inductive auto bed leveling as it was difficult to configure, relatively ineffective and added unnecessary weight to the print head assembly. The auto leveling has to execute before every print as the leveling values are cleared with a home command.

Without the inductive auto bed leveling which requires a metallic surface to function, there was no reason not to add glass to the print bed. The glass print bed eliminates the need for the blue painters tape which is much more of a hassle to use than hair spray. In order to add a glass plate to the aluminum heated bed, I had to get rid of the screw heads, which meant either using flat head screws and counter sinking them into the aluminum bed, or tapping threads into the holes and attaching the screws from the bottom. It would certainly be possible to modify this design to work with countersunk flat head screws if you didn't have a 4mm tap.

I liked the bed leveling adjustment that is available on the Prusa I3 and similar XYZ printers, but these have the adjustment knobs under the bed mounts and springs supporting the bed. This is difficult to duplicate on a delta printer where access to the underside of the bed mounts is not available. By putting the springs under the bed mounts to hold the print bed down I was able to use thumb screws on top of the bed mounts to adjust the height of the bed.

title: Snowball making terminal device
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Snowball making device for young padawans with upper limb prosthetic with 1/2-20 thread adapter.

Snowball diameter = 60mm( slightly smaller than tennis ball)
total lenght of device = 144mm

video of device in use: https://youtu.be/3F43lDbf_rc

note: To make snowball, snow has to be tightly pressed. Just closing top part over the other will not result in a firm ball. Use other hand to press both sides together and then remove the ball.

Printer:

Create 1400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

70%

Notes:

Top was printed splited in half with flat surface towards buildplate and with supports for inner side of sphere.

Bottom part was printed vertical. With flat, proximal side towards buildplate with supports inside of spherical shape.

Both top and bottom parts were printed 35mm/s using 0.6mm nozzle

"pin.stl" & "anchor.stl" was printed 20mm/s, 100%infill

1 - glue togeather top cup. I used ZAP-A-GAP(ethyl cyanocrylate), but any other water resistant glue should do;
2 - assemble top and bottom cup;
3.1 - thread rubber band through hole in top part;
3.2. - thead other end of rubber band through bottom part's hole;
3.3. - fix rubber band in place using "anchor.stl"
4 - attach "pin.stl" through pivot point for top and bottom parts.
5 - insert 1/2-20 1 inch hex screw in proximal adapter with thread towards you(proximal)
6 - tighten proximal adapter to rest of device using 4 screws
7 - post process sphere's inside for smooth surface to avoid snow sticking inside of device.
I used PET tape and laminated inside using heat gun.
optional alternatives: lack, paint, water resistant glue.

Let the Force be with you!

I had the idea to make terminal device which would allow persons with upper limb amputations to participate in snowball fight together with other friends and foes.

Device model was designed in Fusion 360 and adorned using Geomagic Sculpt.

To make device more thematic it's made in Star Wars theme.
If force is not attractive for you - I've uploaded device without adornment as well.

In this work there are incorporated 2 other author designs:
Death Star, published by Juan Gutierrez (embeddedjunkie) - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:245922
Luke Skywalker's Lightsaber - published by TheMM - https://grabcad.com/library/luke-skywalker-s-lightsaber-4

author: Fricis_Pirtnieks

description.text: taranis x7 monitor mount
It has showed too much fragile, but anyways I will upload this, maybe you have a better luck

Grab Toy ++

Introduction:

Had lots of problems printing the amazing Scissor Snake family (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1902131) with hinges fusing together and some parts snapping. So I tried to design a simpler hinge that could also be printed in place using OpenSCAD, where I could play with different spacings between the moving parts.

Then I did the code for the rest of the toy, learning OpenSCAD along the way. Very cool software!

Tips:

Instead of printing the biggest grabtoy here and be disappointed it fused together, you can first check which spacing works better for your printer settings by printing the HingeSlackTest() model.

The default slack of 0.5mm is a good starting point. The lowest I managed when printing PLA at 0.2mm resolution with my Anycubic I3+ at normal (i.e. fast) speed was 0.35, but only at very low temperatures (190º) which results in poorer surface finish.

I found that robustness of the toys varied a lot depending on the slicing software, with some not putting extra material in thin regions that are structurally important (mostly the cores
and shoulders of the hinges). Playing around I realized that some carefully placed thin slits forced the slicers to create extra walls, thus reinforcing some key areas. Enable or disable
them by setting REINFORCE_CORE and REINFORCE_SHOULDER to true or false.

Main routines:

HingeSlackTest() generates a 4-hinge test model with slacks of 0.6, 0.5, 0.4 and 0.3mm. Print it to see how small can you set the spacing for the hinges before they fuse together. Then set the slack parameter accordingly and render one of the grabtoy models below.

GrabToyPlusPlus4hinges() generates the simplest grab toy model, with just one expansion frame.

GrabToyPlusPlus10hinges() makes a bigger grab toy, with 3 expansion frames.

Included STL files:

GTpp_HingeSlackTest.stl: a render of the hinge test model.

GrabToyPlusPlus_4hinges_slack05.stl: render of the short grabtoy, using 0.5mm slack for the hinges.

GrabToyPlusPlus_10hinges_slack05.stl: long grabtoy render, 0.5mm slack.

Enjoy!

title: Rear cupholder for Tesla Model S

description.text:
This is a rear passenger cupholder for Tesla Model S manufactured before September 2016, when rear cupholders became standard.
The design uses two straps that slide under the armrest and are joined with the holder using small nails or paperclips etc. It requires no glueing to the armrest and can be easily removed. The holder folds upwards to give access to the ventilation controls behind. The cups are hollow enough to let the ventilation pass through without any issues.

The holder itself might require some supports around the holes for the cups.

Ps. If you like this design and are planning to buy a new Tesla Model S or X, then please consider using my referral link below, which will give you free Supercharging as long as you own the vehicle:

description.text:
I re-designed the Filament Guide Loop to be a "little" longer.

I removed the spool from the top of the frame and now its sitting behind the printer... i needed a filament guide, the small loop works for small prints that wont take the nozzle very far away from the center of the bed (if you have the clip centered on the frame). As you start to print higher and further away from the center, the filament starts to get bent to make the curve to the extruder so i decided to try out this approach.

Its working quite well..... let me know what you guys think.

In order to get this to work you need to print 2x Filament Guide Clips where you will attach the Long Loop and remember, if the piece doesnt fit your bed size try to print it diagonally.

title: EnLight - LED light for the Creality Ender 2

description.text:
The EnLight is meant to be used with (USB) LED strips. The light bar can be turned to change the angle at what needs to be lid.

Cheap LED strips usually don't stick well which is why I added friction fit "clipper" clips to keep the strips inside the light bar. Be sure to watch out for the cable slot when installing the light and please use 10mm velcro strips for cable management.

The camera mount should work for most action cameras but had been modelled with the SQ11 in mind for which I uploaded the camera mount separately: SQ11mount. Use M5-25 hex head screws and M5 hex nuts to populate "screw" and "nut" of the camera mount. I recently added another camera mount for action cameras that mounts to the Creality Ender 2 bed: EnCam.

There is also a version of this arm for the Prusa i3 - PruLight - and one for the Creality CR-10 printers - CreaLight - that will probably fit many other printers based on open-frame v-slot extruded aluminum bars.

I might add shorter and longer light bars in the future.

Printer:

Creality Ender 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Actually I printed the light bars on a Prusa i3 MK2s but should print without issues on the Creality Ender 2 as these printers are very similar in design. One version of the arms in the photos as well as the action camera mount system were printed on the Creality Ender 2.

To end up with the very same look you will have to slice the arms with 10% to 20% (in my case 15%) honeycomb infill (for example in Slic3r) using 3 or more perimeters and no top or bottom layers. Be sure to have retraction around 20mm/s for 6mm length to prevent nasty stringing. I used the same settings for the wheel which also looks good printed with top/bottom. If the arm seems too wobbly you might want to print with a different filament or with top/bottom. In my case the arm is plenty strong.

The light bar as well as all the other parts work well with default settings for 0.1 mm to 0.2 mm layer height but can tend to get a bit tight at 0.2mm height or more.

As easy as 1, 2, 3 ...

Just put a USB LED strip with the USB cable oriented towards the cable slot into the light bar and carefully cut it to lengths. Then remove the protection and glue it to the light bar. Add a few (i.e. 3) clippers about equally spaced apart from each other to keep the LED strip in place. Be sure to not cover LEDs or electric components but just the strip/tape instead. Install the arm between filament holder and Z axis, then slide the bar in from the right and add the wheel like a cap from the left. The wheel can turn the light bar.

In case your LED strip is not flat but a few mm heigh be sure to clip the clippers to length.

Use 10mm velcro for cable management.

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Zero W case for compatible asian NoIR camera

title: Raspberry Pi Zero W case for compatible asian NoIR camera (nuts-n-bolts remix)

description.text:
I was too lazy to go to the hardware store for the M6 and M4 screws and nuts, so I used the "Nut Job" scad (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647) to mix up some printable ones. They seem strong enough for me. There was also something in the base's original design that blocked the M4 nut from going down on one side (you can see it in thingiview), so I converted it to a threaded M6 hole to use the same size bolt as the others. Then I needed to make the hole in the mounting bracket 6mm to match, so also fixed the one side that wasn't quite flush.

Update 1/15/2018:
I made some V2 wingnuts that are a little tighter because I did strip one out.
Also wanted to mount my camera horizontally so remixed the back cover.

Update 1/16/2018:
I took down my camera to add a garage door open/close feature and noticed the housing was fairly warm, so I remixed the back cover to have some vents.

Update 1/25/2018:
I did want the two little holes in the front cover so mixed them out.

Update 2/6/2018 (V2):
Remixed the front cover to have "snaps" to hold the NoIR camera in place.
Remixed the back cover to go vertical, offset, and more vents.
Remixed the mount to go horizontal.

Update 2/21/2018 (V3):
Noticed that the cpu temp of the camera in the garage was running in the upper 70s, so created another remix to hold a 30mm fan. Found that running it off the 3.3v keeps it quiet and the cpu is now in the low 40s.
Also found that the "snaps" in V2 for the NoIR camera break pretty easily so changed those to be standoffs that take screws where the heads of the screws catch on the edge of the camera (forgot to take a pic).
Also remixed the back to have standoffs for the 5v relay.

Update 2/23/2018 (V4):
The cpu temp on my other camera was also hitting the upper 70s even though it is "outside" (under the porch) and it has been pretty cool outside.
So I remixed it again to have a fan on top, and also rotated the vents on the end 90 degrees so they print nicer by bridging.
The standoffs for the camera are still pretty easy to break when putting in screws so I started pre-tapping them by just getting the screw started, holding the tip of a soldering iron against the screw head for just a second, then continue screwing them in.
Took pics of each step of assembly this time and how I tap the fan into the 3.3v
The one inside the garage (V3) the fan is on the bottom and and I set it to blow air into the case, whereas the one on the porch (V4) the fan is on top and I set it to suck the air out and it seems to run a few degrees cooler in the upper 30s, so it is possible that sucking is better than blowing.

Update 3/2/2018 (V5):
Remixed the front to be fully enclosed with thicker standoffs for the camera.
Remixed the back to mount the fan and vents on back.

Feel free to ask any questions, these are great little devices.

comments.text: Any problems with durability of the electronics when mounting outdoors on your covered porch? I'm hoping to install on my front porch underneath an awning. I live in Massachusetts, not sure if moisture/heat will be a problem...

We do live near the coast though and it is fairly humid most of the time, but I am thinking the fan and cpu temps will keep the inside from collecting any moisture. comments.author: dbgeorge

comments.text:
That is great! I am really impressed with motionEye, have mine sending email notifications and uploading to google drive on motion detection. The 5v relay is for the one in the garage to simulate pushing to garage door button so I can close the door from anywhere if I forget to leave it open. It is easy to use "Action Buttons" in motionEye to do gpio (https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki/Action-Buttons). I also now have connected a magnetic switch that monitors the door state, and emails me when it open, closes, or stays open. You can use the "Monitor" feature in motionEye to do that pretty easily too (https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneye/wiki/Monitoring-Commands). In case it isn't obvious, I'm very paranoid of forgetting to leave the garage door open haha. I attached a screen shot of the one in the garage where you can see the extra action buttons, and the extra text that gives temp, door state, and if the door state monitoring is on/off.
Relay: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XAGT052
Fan: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072FW3DDQ

remixed_from.author: ml_blh
remixed_from.title: Anycubic I3 Mega Power Supply Casing

description.text:
FR
Le ventilateur de l'alimentation de l'Anycubic I3 Mega est bruyant. Je voulais y installer un ventilateur Kaze-Jyu Slim (100x100x12 mm) qui est particulièrement silencieux. Il faut l'installer à cheval sur le support prévu pour un ventilateur de 100 mm de façon à ce qu'il ne butte pas sur les condensateurs et permette de pouvoir refermer le châssis de l'imprimante.

Il suffit pour le caler de couper les pattes pour les vis du ventilateur à chaque coin du fichier original, de coller 2 triangles à une extrémité, de l'insérer au milieu du support en forçant un peu et de le caler avec le blocage.
Quelques trous de 3mm à la perceuse au niveau des triangles et du blocage, on utilise les vis longues fournies avec le ventilateur et on visse 4 écrous M3.

Pour ceux qui n'auraient pas encore imprimé le superbe couvercle de l'alimentation de ml_blh, j'ai joint des modèles avec les triangles déjà en place. Dans ce dernier cas, il n'est pas nécessaire de visser le ventilateur, la pièce de blocage venant d'insérer dans des picots. Vous pouvez sécuriser la pièce de blocage avec 2 vis M3x8mm. (voir dernières photos)
L'ensemble ne touche pas les condensateurs de l'alimentation et ne gène pas l'installation de la partie inférieure de l'imprimante (il faudra retourner à 180° pour une bonne ventilation par les ouïes)

J'ai choisi de mettre le ventilateur de l'alimentation soufflant vers les composants. L'imprimante étant dans un caisson avec une ventilation propre, les flux d'air ne sont pas ainsi contrariés. Le ventilateur de l'alimentation tourne à 1000tr/mn, une autre identique est fixé sur la paroi inférieure du châssis, et refroidit efficacement la carte mère et les drivers 2208. Il faut aussi remplacer le ventilateur droit de la tête d’impression par un Noctua de 40mm, et lors d'une impression, le silence est alors impressionnant !

Edit: Plusieurs versions plus ou moins ajourées sont fournies. Si vous mettez le ventilateur en mode extraction, pensez à imprimer la pièce blocage en mode miroir sur sa plus grande longueur pour permettre le passage du câble du ventilateur.

Edit 2 : Le dernier stl positionne le ventilateur du coté opposé aux condensateurs.

ENG
The power supply fan of the Anycubic I3 Mega is noisy. I wanted to install a fan Kaze-Jyu Slim (100x100x12 mm) which is particularly quiet. It must be mounted astride the support provided for a 100 mm fan so that it does not interfere with the capacitors and allows to close the chassis of the printer.

Just stall it to cut the tabs for the fan screws at each corner of the original file, stick 2 triangles at one end, insert it in the middle of the support by forcing a little and stall with the blocking.
A few holes of 3mm with the drill at the triangles and the blocking, we use the long screws supplied with the fan and screwed 4 nuts M3.

For those who have not yet printed the superb chassis for power supply from ml_blh. I have attached some models with the triangles already in place. In this case, it is not necessary to screw the fan, the locking piece just inserted into pins. You can secure the locking piece with 2 M3x8mm screws. (see last images)
The assembly does not touch the capacitors of the power supply and does not interfere with the installation of the lower part of the printer (it will be necessary to flip it to 180 ° for a good ventilation by the gills)

I chose to put the blower towards the components. The printer being in a box with clean ventilation, the air flows are not so upset. The fan of the power supply runs at 1000 rpm, another identical is fixed on the bottom wall of the chassis, and effectively cools the motherboard and drivers 2208. It is also necessary to replace the right fan of the print head by a Noctua 40mm, and during an impression, the silence is impressive!

Edit: Several more or less openwork versions are provided. If you are putting the fan into extraction mode, consider printing the mirror blocking part the longest way to allow the fan cable to pass through.

Edit2 : The last stl positions the fan on the opposite side to the capacitors.

This is a program in the Processing language that creates image height maps from JPG and other supported file formats. It has decimation with averaging and a dots per inch adjustment, plus you can change the input filename to match your photo.
Note that it does not make a 3D version of the image, it just makes a box for each pixel and sets the height to each group of pixel's average intensity. The result, for the image shown does look a bit like a 3D image of my friend because her face is light and her hair and eyes are dark.
The purpose of this program is to create a sort of 3D printed image braille especially for blind and visually impaired people. You can make art, street signs, business nameplates, etc. that are readable with fingers. In fact, why are we printing street signs within reach any other way?

You need to be familiar with the Processing programming language, know someone who is, or get that way yourself to run this code. Go to www.processing.org to learn everything Processing.
Your image goes in the sketch's data folder, you set your parameters at the top of the file, and the result is written out as output.obj in the sketch's folder. Some tweaking may be required to get the dots per inch and the decimation correct for your intended purpose. Enjoy!

comments.text: HI cerebrus333, yes Processing compiles to an executable program of the type that you are running.  So for example if you are on a PC you get a PC executable.  Mac makes Mac executables and Linux makes Linux executables.  I am on a Mac so it wouldn't help much to make an executable for non-Mac users, plus it's a good practice to compile little sketches like this from source code to prevent the spread of viruses and other nasties.

author: Larrob631

description.text:
This is a modificationen for the Zhiyun Smooth-Q Gimbal to attach any kind of compact camera. I tried it with the Sony RX-100 IV and it works pretty well! The Camera is slightly heavier than the maximum load for the gimbal, but if you balance it well it should work fine. It's not official and you might loose your warranty, so you do it on your own risk and I won't take any responsibilities if you break your gimbal.
I included a cap to cover the M6 bolt and a little tool to tighten the M6 nut. You don't necessarily need them.
If you have any questions or some improvement ideas, let me know!

What else do you need?

1x M6x30mm bolt
3x M3 nuts
2x M4x40mm bolt(I used M4x50 but 40 will do as well)
2x M4 nuts
a couple of washer of different sizes and weights as counterweights(I used 2x 15x44, 2x 11x34, 1x 6,6x22)
1x 1/4 bolt to attach the camera

Modification

Put the two parts together with the M4 bolts as seen in the rendering. Now just remove the smartphone clamp from the gimbal(check some youtube videos) and use the M6x30mm screw to mount the new part. Fix it on the outside with a nut and put the washer on the screw till the camera(with extended lens) is more or less balanced without the gimbal powered on. Then fix the smallest washer with the last nut, turn on the gimbal, press three times the mode button to make the gimbal face the other direction and you are ready to go!

What are the 3x M3 nuts needed for in your instructions?

comments.author: Aknoon

comments.text:
I ordered the print on 3dhubs. I think it was kind of a wooden PLA filament(100 μm). I took it because I didn't like the other color available and I was curious about the wooden material. Unfortunately I don't have any experience with the strength of other materials, but in case you are worried about the stability with the camera on, just print it with any kind of material, put it together and try to bend it with your fingers. I think most of the materials are stable enough as long as you use enough infill.
Maybe let me know when you have any experience with different materials. :)

author: n00bie

description.text: This is a simple box that is designed to hold a piece of 2" x 3.5" x 0.063" titanium plate. The titanium plate is designed to hold 24 seed words, which can be used to restore a cryptocurrency software or hardware wallet, for bitcoin, litecoin, etherium, etc. The box adds only aesthetic appeal and prevents prying eyes from reading the seed words. The seed words are punched or engraved onto the titanium plate, which acts as a long term storage device.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

What is it?

This is a 3d-printed box or storage container, designed to hold a piece of titanium plate. The titanium plate contains the user's seed words, which can be used to restore either a software or hardware wallet, in the event the wallet is lost, destroyed, compromised, etc. For more on seed words, see: https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/45978/what-is-the-wallet-word-seed-that-is-commonly-used-in-popular-wallets-clients

The design uses a 2" x 3.5" x 0.063" piece of titanium (stainless steel can be used as well), which can be purchased on eBay, Amazon, etc. I used a straight-edge, and a razor knife to make the dividing lines, dividing the titanium plate into 24 boxes, which can each contain one seed word. The horizontal lines should be approximately 7.5 mm apart, which will leave slightly more than 7.5 mm on the top and bottom, so you should measure from the center. The vertical line is centered, so 1" in from either side.

The screws I used were #6-32 x 3/8 stainless steel machine screws from Home Depot.

You may find it helpful to drill out the countersunk holes on the base piece, so that the screws simply passes through to the lid, and then get threaded into the lid piece.

description.text:
One of our favorite activities in the spring and summer is to take a few model rockets down to the local baseball field and launch them. My two kids really love it, and I like that they get involved with painting the rockets.

The toilet-paper tubes that I designed these for are the Great-Value Brand from Wal-Mart. The quality control on the inside diameter of the rolls is not great; so, some will be tighter then others. The diameter was designed to print at 42mm.

The model rocket is designed to accommodate an "Estes Class A." Sometimes, Estes list these as "Standard Class." ***EDIT****: So, we had some uncommonly warm weather today (1-13-2018). I took this rocket out with one of the larger "pay-load" rockets. I would say that an "A Class" engine is undersized. No worries! You can use a standard "C Class" engine. They have the same dimensions. I used a C6-3 and it seemed quite perfect for a windy day. Maybe 200ft best guess.

Enjoy and please, be safe.

Printer:

Reprap ANET A8 Clone Melzi

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I used touching build-plate for supports due to the internal parts that are elevated off the plate. I used PLA as the print material.
Forget the haters! Real engineers only use AutoCAD!

comments.text: I'm just adding a note here about the above edit. "A-Class" engines are under-powered for the weight of this model. I used a C6-3 class to get about 200ft. of altitude at apex.
comments.author: transformertester

comments.text: Just as a side note. Most of the kit rockets have a metal clip to retain the model rocket engine inside the engine holder. I used a paper-clip. I used 5-minuet epoxy to secure it and then bent it up to hold insure that it would remain in the engine chamber. However, I recomend using your head and figure out your own "best way."
comments.author: transformertester

comments.text: When I have printed rockets I just add a 4mm wide slot and slide the clip in so that it fits in this slot, glue that down and then mount the arrangement in the fin can.  That holds the motor very nicely.  I love the idea of using TP or even kitchen paper/paper towel rolls.  And several couplers and a bit of scale up or down can allow the use of D motors, or C11-3s if you want.  The permutations are endless!

Assembly
  1. Attach the geared bed mount to the print bed underneath the heated built surface.
  2. Attach the phone plate to the geared bed mount using the small bolt and nut. Adjust the positioning by loosening or removing this bolt.
  3. Thread the long bolt through the phone plate. Add (optional) riser nuts to adjust the height of the phone.
  4. Slide both phone brackets onto the long bolt facing each other, placing the phone between them.
  5. Gently thread the remaining bolt, and further adjust phone positioning before tightening.

author: john3d

description.text:
I have done a bit of work designing 3D printed frames for 2.5" propeller class FPV quadcopters. However, I just keep coming back to durability issues with many of my designs (I can only print in PLA, so), and that really limits my ability to have flight time. So, I decided to use a carbon fiber frame, the Airblade Creampuff.

The frame comes with 3D printed mounts for a larger camera, but I am using a small, Tiny Whoop-style all-in-one camera/vtx, so I needed a camera mount. I separated the camera and vtx boards to be able to mount the antenna out the back of the quad, so this camera mount is designed to only hold the camera plate. I have included pictures of the wiring that I did for my camera/vtx so you can get an idea of what it looks like if you would like to complete a similar modification. Definitely look up wiring for your specific camera if possible.

The pictures of the mount aren't the greatest as I broke my first print and nothing is secured well. The camera is held at a 30 degree angle.
Using 2nd generation cardboard lenses to load on the frame.

I created this snowflake for our Christmas tree. It was my first time using BlocksCAD...
You will have to print 2 copies of the part, to stick them together and get a 3-dimensional snowflake, to hang wherever you want. I love it in white, but you can choose any color that fits your decor.

I hope you have fun with this design :-)

First time using BlocksCAD!
Played a little bit with the functions in BlocksCAD, as it is different than usual CAD programs (usually I use SolidWorks, but also worked with CATIA, Siemens NX and ProEngineer - the principle is always the same). For me, it was more difficult to create this thing with BocksCAD than with Solidworks, where I would have created a sketch and then would have extruded it. In BlocksCAD you have to use different kinds of functions in the style of a computer program - but with easy understandable "blocks" which you put together to get your program - definitely fun to use :-)

title: Chip Off the Block
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed by Ken Maher (https://kenmgames.wordpress.com/).
Set Up: Place the Chips in the middle of the Table within easy reach of all players and give
the Die to the youngest player.
How To Play: On your turn do the following (1) Roll the die. (2) Take or Give a Chip. (3) Pass the die to the player on your left.
Taking a Chip: When you roll the die, the number that comes up is the chip you get to take. Claim it either from the middle of the table, or from the player currently holding it.
Giving a Chip: If you roll a “1” you must give one of your chips to another player. Your choice. (Make them beg!) If you currently hold no chips you may make another player give one of their chips back into the middle of the table. (Their Choice if they have more than one.)
Winning: When the last chip is claimed from the middle of the table every player turns their
chips over and adds up the score on the back. The highest total wins.

This is a crystalline snowflake I created for the #BlocksCADSnowflake contest. I plan on printing it out shortly and will update with additional photos.

This is a set of 2 separate organizers that I made for 7 Wonders Duel (including the Pantheon Expansion).

The first organizer holds all of the components you will need during the game (Age cards, money, and progress tokens) with a snug little spot for a pen or pencil.

The second organizer holds the remaining components that you only need at the beginning of the game during set up (wonder cards, deity cards, score pads, and other tokens).

Both organizers fit snugly into the box with enough room to keep the board(s) and instructions on top. Enjoy! Please post pictures of game play if you print these!

title: Toy 1:10 H015 Sentry Droid (Star Wars: The Force Awakens & The Last Jedi)

description.text:
This is a 1:10 scale "toy" H015 Sentry Droid. It's been modified heavily to print OK at 1:10 scale. Most notably the antennae and other thin/tiny details (though the Lego Greeblies on the bottom print OK, so they get to stay).

If you print it at 55% of this size (5.5% of life size), then it is about perfect for the 3 3/4" Star Wars figures. The tolerances for the parts are aimed more at the bigger size, so you may have to sand a little to get the top attached to the bottom.

We build Lego Star Wars droids, so when I learned about H015 in The Force Awakens, we decided to build it. (This was before we'd even seen it - BB-8 was already on our agenda though). You can check out our Lego full-scale build log on RebelDroids.net

For various reasons, the Lego droid has been complicated. Our original plans "skirt" didn't fit around the Lego at the bottom. We know Lego, the Lego was right, so that meant the 3D model needed help.

After carefully reviewing photos taken from Star Wars Celebration: London, we were able to get it figured out - good enough for a toy anyway.

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

Low - 10%

Notes:

The head and antenna could be printed as one, the separate models is a legacy of how I designed the model. However if you break the antennae, they're easier to reprint if they're not on the head. Maybe easier to paint to.

The head & antenna are printed right-side-up. The body is printed upside-down. Supports almost aren't needed, but I used a few:

  • Around the "neck" in the head I didn't trust it, so I let the slicer add supports there.
  • Where the neck goes in the head could use support. That area isn't visible though
  • Around the "waist" of the body (black zig-zag line) each side has a platform that sticks out and could use support when printed upside down.

comments.text: FWIW: To be in scale with the 3.75" figures this should need to be about 55% of the size of this model... I'll let you know if my print works :)

description.text: Tailight housings for the 57 ford f100 style rc body. I made it for a HPI body but the others would likely fir fine.

downloaded a picture of a f7 ford f100 tailight lens. Used an online converter to convert from .png to .svg format. imported svg into 123d design and extruded to length, then using the combine tool i deleted the angle of the fender to allow them to point straight back.

glued them to the rear fender of the rc body, drilled through and inserted red leds from behind. using an extra print i shaped some red lexan to match the outline and glued them over the housing. I will be making up an arduino controller for the lights, and posting it with my other projects on arduino create.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed it with full infill and .2mm but you may be able to squeeze a little more detail out of .1mm.  I tried printing with brim 3mm and a raft.  The brim had the best result.

title: T-Rex Skeleton
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.header: A ready-to-print model that's back from extinction

description.text: The T-Rex model is a great educational tool that's 20 times smaller than the real-life skeleton of the mighty Tyrannosaurus Rex. Whether you're using it in the classroom or adding it your collection, you'll take pride in knowing it's built accurately to scale.
From tail to teeth, this carnivore is created exactly in the image of its ancestor. No details were spared, from its intricate skull, to its delicate ribcage, to its laughably small arms.

This lizard king is at home in the classroom as well as in a dinophile's collection. Simple to print with PDF assembly instructions, T-Rex is a unique addition for all kinds of lesson plans and other fun uses.

comments.text: I printed the skull twice without supports and got terrible overhangs; rough and irregular. As it built the arches the tip of the partial arch would curl upwards and really throw off the print. It literally threw it off the bed once when the nozzle caught it. I'm a newbie so there is any number of things I could have done wrong. I had my print retraction too low to start and got terrible blobbing. Making it larger reduced the blobbing. The next print I'm trying supports to see if that improves the overhangs. I'm using a Printrbot Metal Plus and Cura 15.04.3., generic PLA at 205º,  40mm/s, etc.
comments.author: paverko

comments.text: I had similar issues with some of my parts and this is more of a cooling issue I found then anything else with supports. This stood out specially on the parts that had a angle to them. I semi corrected this by rotating the part so that the cooling fan would hit these elements and allow it to cool a bit before the next layer and this showed some improvement. This print is really rough on some parts I'm finding and really puts the printer through its paces with all the angles it has and some of the parts are just not printer friendly like the rib segments.

comments.text: I printed all parts with a brim rather then a raft. It added needed support for some of the parts, like the skull, which have a very small bed surface area. Also used a skirt (the quick outline around a model on bed surface, prior to printing the model), as this for my printer is just the right amount of time for the extruder to be fully & properly primed to print the model. The brim adds surface area to the base of most of the parts in this porject, which is needed, to achieve proper surface support. I had fantastic results while printing, and just need to complete the tail and appendages now to complete the project.

comments.text: Anyone else have issues printing the tail using Cura? Half way through the print, it prints one layer like garbage. It's underextruded or something. comments.author: chevy07

comments.text: Well boys and girls, I found the issue. I took a section of the model in Netfabb and it appears that there is literally a gap in the model between the joints I described. Therefore, the slicer is just following the model and "skipping" a layer and that's why it's weak at that point. Hopefully Makerbot can fix their model so others don't continue to have this issue.
comments.author: chevy07

comments.text: Tail B appears to also have this issue (as I saw when printing). But this model appears to have separation between 3 of the joints! (I experienced the issue on joint 2). I understand that depending on your layer height, your 3D printer can soak up these gaps and not mind. I personally was printing at .18mm layer height, which while is fairly detailed layer height it's definitely not the finest that others are doing by a long shot, so I hope makerbot is able to correct this
comments.author: chevy07

comments.author: TheScorpion

comments.text: l printed this out this past week.  I was very pleased.  I first started on the Makerbot Stegosaurus.  With that model I had to trim all parts to go together and I am having to superglue a rib at a time as they do not print well for me and the holes and pins are too small for an additive printer to do well.  However, the TRex is a different story.  The pins and holes are as large as you can get them with long pens with spaces to allow them to collapse together for effective fit.  The TRex went together for me without trimming except the ribs.  The ribs worked hugely better than the Stego... I did superglue the ribs but had that done in a day whilst Im slowly still working on Stego ribs and plates gluing one at a time using clamps and such to hold them since there is no such thing as 10 second superglue (or 30 second either).  Good Job, TRex Maker!  Also I was able to print the TRex without support (only brim) without any issues on a TAZ5 using Makerbot 1.75 Warm Gray.  Though TAZ is setup for 3mm, I find MB PLA 1.75 to be the best performing filament I've used.  Other PLA brands I use become too brittle except when in humid climes and ABS and HIPS is quite poor printing accurate pins and holes such as are found on this model due to shrinkage..  To print 1.75 on TAZ you only need to adjust first layer to adhere and indicate filament diameter. PS - I had no issues resulting from nonmanifold meshes... maybe due to Cura's fix horrible default settings.
comments.author: lingvistika

comments.text: Great item to print, but as others have said many non manifold meshes - but really you should always check files before printing them. I found Slic3r detected and fixed all the problems, more than meshmixers inspector could, or blenders manifold checker. The only thing i've seen with better watertight checks is Zbrush, but its not cheap. The hardest thing I've found to print on this is the tail, use a good amount of infil, even print the small end tail seperately. Even if you don't use Slic3r for slicing, it has a simple repair function and outputs OBJ files, it's pretty darn good for a freebie.

comments.text: I ran the tail through slic3r and split it up so I could print on piece at a time.  The Tail D section that seems to be missing a large chunk just would not repair correctly, and I was about to give up but I found a pretty simple solution - upload just the affected section to Tinkercad and then export it again as an STL.  It seems to have filled in the model correctly and it's headed off to the printer right now - I'll update once it's done and we'll see how it went.

I had one rib fall at about 70% but I used ABS at 0.15 mm layer height with cooling fan on and the rest printed great. I had just a bit of cleanup of strings thanks to the fallen rib. I just tipped it off with some white abs/acetone mix and it will just be a broken rib.
The only way to get these to print with ABS is at least 3 shells perimeter and with a level glass bed + glue stick with the cooling fan at 100% starting only after 10-15 layers high.

comments.text: This is actually not scientifically accurate. The arms are (believe it or not) a bit too long, the tail flexes too much vertically (it should look straight when viewed from the side, they could flex horizontally but not vertically), and it's wrists are not oriented properly (a theropods dinosaurs palms should face each other, not inwards).

author: mr_earth

description.text:
This is a parameterized hyperbolic curve rotated around its transverse axis to make a solid.

Both horizontal and vertical versions are in the OpenSCAD script! Adjust to make the hyperbolic solid of your dreams!

Horizontal gives the results we needed with rotate_extrude, but the vertical axis shape is fun and possibly useful too.

This solid was designed to be part of a multi-reflector cassegrain style antenna design for 122GHz amateur radio inspired by Paul Wade W1GHZ's writeup. Link below!

Find out more about the 3D printable 122GHz antenna system at:
https://github.com/Abraxas3d/122GHz

And here is Paul Wade's writeup:
http://www.w1ghz.org/antbook/conf/Multiple_reflector_antennas.pdf

OpenSCAD Script

//Hyperbolic Solid in OpenSCAD
//by Michelle Thompson @abraxas3d

//A hyperbola is the set of all points where the difference
//in the distance from intstwo fixed po is a constant.

//What we are after here is the positive half of a hyperbola.
//We then rotate it around its transverse axis in order
//to make a hyperbolic surface.

//This hyperbolic surface is then 3D printed in order to
//provide a prototype subreflector for a microwave cassegrain
//antenna system for radio experimentation.

//equation for a hyperbola is (x^2)/(a^2) - (y^2)/(b^2) = 1
// x = a sec(angle)
// y = b tan(angle)
// angle varies from 0 to pi/2

//a and b are the dimensions of the box that defines the
//asymptotes of the hyperbolic curve.
a = 40; //affects height of the vertex above origin and how tall shape ends up.
b = 40; //radius

//resolution variable in OpenSCAD. Higher numbers mean smoother surface.
$fn = 200;

max_angle = 45; //affects how tall the shape ends up.
angle_resolution = 0.5;

//granularity should match the length of the polygon vector
//before we add the two finishing points that complete a closed curve.
granularity = max_angle/angle_resolution;

//Depending on the behavior desired, one might want either
//a vertical or a horizontal hyperbolic curve.
//choose which one here.
//set horizontal to true for horizontal (creates the right shape when rotated).
//set horizontal to false for vertical (creates an interesting shape when rotated).
horizontal = true;

//For horizontal case:
//we are defining functions that make a vector of points.
//each point is a vector in and of itself in the form [x,y]
//the vector of points follows a horizontal hyperbolic curve.
//the independent variable is the angle from 0 to max_angle.
//we use concat() to build the vector of points as long as
//we do not exceed the max_angle. we increment by angle_resolution
//and then calculate a new set of points.
//secant is the reciprocal of cosine
function horiz_hyper(angle) = angle < max_angle ? concat([[btan(angle), a(1/(cos(angle)))]], horiz_hyper(angle + angle_resolution)) : [];

//For vertical case:
//we are defining functions that make a vector of points.
//each point is a vector in and of itself in the form [x,y]
//the vector of points follows a vertical hyperbolic curve.
//the independent variable is the angle from 0 to max_angle.
//we use concat() to build the vector of points as long as
//we do not exceed the max_angle. we increment by angle_resolution
//and then calculate a new set of points.
//secant is the reciprocal of cosine
function vert_hyper(angle) = angle < max_angle ? concat([[ a(1/(cos(angle))) , btan(angle)]], vert_hyper(angle + angle_resolution)) : [];

if (horizontal == true) {

//we have a hyperbolic curve, but it needs to be closed so
//that we can turn it into a polygon and then rotate to get a solid.

//uncomment this block for checks
/*
//check the length of the vector
echo(len(horiz_hyper(0)));

//check the last entry
echo(horiz_hyper(0)[granularity - 1]);

//check the y value from the last set of points.
echo(horiz_hyper(0)[granularity - 1][1]);

//check entire list of points.
echo(horiz_hyper(0));
*/

//get the y value from the last set of points.
replace_horiz = horiz_hyper(0)[granularity - 1][1];

//add two points to the curve to close it, using concat().
//first, stay at current y value, but set x to zero so that
//we come across to the y axis to make the top of the polygon.
//then, drop straight down to where we started.
full_set_horiz = concat(horiz_hyper(0), [[0, replace_horiz]], [[0,a]]);

//show the polygon we created.
/
translate([0, 0, 0]) polygon(full_set_horiz);
/

//use rotate_extrude to rotate the 2d polygon and make it a 3d shape.
//translate moves it to origin. Set -a to 0 if you want it to be at
//its calculated position!
translate([0, 0, -a]) rotate_extrude(angle = 360, convexity = 10) polygon(full_set_horiz);

} else {

//we have a hyperbolic curve, but it needs to be closed so
//that we can turn it into a polygon and then rotate to get a solid.

//uncomment this block for checks
/*
//check the length of the vector
echo(len(vert_hyper(0)));

//check the last entry
echo(vert_hyper(0)[granularity - 1]);

//check the x value from the last set of points.
echo(vert_hyper(0)[granularity - 1][0]);

//check entire list of points.
echo(vert_hyper(0));
*/

//get the x value from the last set of points.
replace_vert = vert_hyper(0)[granularity - 1][0];

//add two points to the curve to close it, using concat().
//first, stay at current x value, but set y to zero so that
//we come across to the x axis to make the top of the polygon.
//then, drop straight down to where we started.
full_set_vert = concat(vert_hyper(0), [[replace_vert, 0]], [[a,0]]);

//show the polygon we created.
/
translate([0, 0, 0]) polygon(full_set_vert);
/

//use rotate_extrude to rotate the 2d polygon and make it a 3d shape.
rotate_extrude(angle = 360, convexity = 10) translate([0, 0, 0]) polygon(full_set_vert);

}

description.text:
I bought a Hobbyking Desert Fox buggy for my son... and then a Quanum Vandal for myself,

While out doing donuts in the snow my son struck something and broke the lower control arm and steering knuckle. The parts are backordered and experience tells me that they may be months off.... so I decided to design my own replacement part.

This part should fit the Desert Fox and Vandal... as well as a few other makes/models (VTX)

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

Solid (100%)

Notes:

I printed this part with the upper control arm boss on the bottom.

My M150 had trouble printing the supports for the sides of the boss, but I let it run and it came out as a usable part.

The PLA is holding up so far.
I drilled out the control-arm pin hole to suit the pin and the other three holes I drilled and tapped to 3x0.5 to suit the existing bolts.

I designed this part in AutoCAD 2007.

Tried to stay as close to the original part as possible.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8Um6DCPWmec
I made this to hang my Hakko soldering station to clear space on my bench. The support have a 30 degrees angle from the wall.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8Um6DCPWmec
This handle is large enough for a small to medium hand size. This is my first design so if it is a little wonky I am sorry.

description.text:
This is a blank mask. Nothing too special about it. If you print it out as is it's slightly disturbing, but it makes a good base for a lot of different projects (For example: http://www.instructables.com/id/THEY-LIVE-alien-costumes/). It's also fun to paint designs on.

It is sized for the average human face. Those of you with big heads may need to up it by about 5%. The top has been flattened for easy printing, as such I recommend you orient the model so it prints upside down (forehead on the printer base, chin towards the sky).

Alternatively you can use this mask as a base to 3D sculpt a perfectly wearable mask in your favorite sculpting program (Right now I use Sculptris or Blender). I've included the .obj file for easy importing into Sculptris as well.

title: Flash Forge Creator Pro Magnetic Detachable Door Hinge

description.text: Magnetically detachable hinge for Flash Forge Creator Pro top hinge door model. I designed this hinge so I could easily remove the door for printing with PLA. This may also work for the side hinge model if you feel the need to remove the door. The original top half of the hinge and pin are used along with the printed parts. I used 12.7 x 6.3 mm neodymium rare earth magnets in my print I had them around and don't recall the supplier but the files can be remixed for other magnet sizes. In order for the hinge to work properly you will require magnets powerful enough to hold through the Plexiglas door.This model was designed with On Shape, sliced with Simplify 3D and printed in PLA. You will need to print two each of the backing and hinge and four of the dowel. All original fasteners work.
