author: Tman12000

print_settings.Notes:: NOTE:

description.text:
I created this lamp to make use of cheap RGB LED strips. The main model has been tailored to fit this Amazon listing. More information about the LEDs, the model, instructions, and pictures can all be found in the appropriate section below. (Before printing anything, please see the instructions!)

Feedback means a lot to me, so if you like the design or make one yourself, please let me know! Happy printing!

I used a strip of RGB LEDs off of Amazon (available here) mainly because of their price--an affordable $17. The listing provided comes with a power adapter, a remote control, and more than enough LEDs for the project. The quality of the LEDs is lacking, but their performance is acceptable, and their price makes them perfect for the project!

These LEDs have a small infrared receptor for the remote, and so there is a hole in the Shade_Plate.stl to allow it to fit through. There is also a small hole in the back of that part for the power cord to exit the base through. The well in the Base_Plate.stl file is designed to fit the adapter for the LEDs listed. Should you decide to use a different kind of LED, I have provided different versions of these parts without the receptor hole and well. They are called Shade_Plate_No_Hole.stl and Base_Plate_No_Well.stl respectively.

There are five pieces in total to print:

1) Lamp_Shade.stl: The lamp shade. This piece should be printed in white or with some translucent material. This piece does NOT need supports!
2) Shade_Base.stl: The base which supports the shade. This piece has shallow grooves which hold the lamp shade in place so it does not slide off the base.
3) Base_Plate.stl: The bottom of the lamp upon which the shade base sits.
4) LED_Core.stl: The central core around which the LEDs are wrapped. This piece is largely hollow to save plastic. There is a hole in the bottom to allow the LEDs to pass through.
5) Top_Cap.stl: A small cap which keeps most light from shining out of the top.

Print the pieces in any order. Print all pieces in the orientation provided for best results. I used a 0.2mm layer height with a 10% infill, and a 1mm shell thickness for all parts. NOTE: There is very little tolerance between the shade plate and base plate. This is by design, the pieces should fit together with pressure alone. If the pieces will not fit, sand the vertical edges of the base plate.

Assembly only requires a bit of glue (I used hot glue, but superglue will also work). I've included a photo of the final assembly.

1) Feed the LEDs through the hole of the LED core. Now, peel off the adhesive from the back of the LED strip, and tightly wrap the LEDs all the way up the pole. (The adhesive isn't very good, so a dab of glue every once in a while--especially at the end--is a good idea.) Cut them with scissors to the correct length.
2) Once the glue dries and the LEDs are secure, line the depressed ring in the bottom of the shade plate with glue, and insert the LED core through the hole. Make sure the rod is aligned straight up! Let the glue dry.
3) Seat the white adapter box for the LEDs into the well on the base plate. I glued mine down, but this is not required. Feed the infrared receptor through the hole, and make sure that it is fit snugly so it does not fall back in. Do NOT glue it in place.
4) Connect the white adapter box to the LEDs, and connect the black power cable into the box. Make sure the cable goes through the small square gap, and press the shade base and base plate together. The fit should be snug.
5) Put the lamp shade over the LED core. It should sit in the grooves of the shade base. Drop the cap in the hole (there will be no resistance). Plug it in and enjoy!

The completed assembly. The white adapter box is glued into the well of the base plate.
The finished lamp, set to fade between colors.

This design was inspired by Nik Markellov's amazing wave lamps and vases. I had multiple errors printing one of his wave lamps and instead challenged myself to design something similar. This model was created with OnShape, a fantastic cloud-based CAD program. From conception to final product took around four days.

Including plastic and LEDs, the entire lamp costs around $25 to create.

It's possible your LEDs are brighter and hotter than the ones I used! You could also always wrap the LEDs less densely around the core.

author: kevinorion

title: IKEA Office Chair Markus Armrest Screw and Bolt

description.text:
Screw and bolt to fasten the armchair cover on the IKEA Markus office chair. Make sure to print the bolt with enough infill so it doesn't buckle under strain.

Why did you need this?

I have moved several times in my life and every time I move I buy a new desk and chair (distanse is too great to bring the old stuff). I always donate my old stuff and I though this time I'm not going to buy new stuff as I'll only be living here for a couple of years. I'll become more sustainable and get something used instead. I signed up for a email alert every time someone in the city posted a desk and chair they wanted to give away. And now a couple of weeks later I have a desk and chair that really fits my work space, saving me money and the environment the burden of the production of another desk and chair.

But in this orgy of self righteousness and smugness there was a small problem. One of the armchair cover's fastner was missing. So I decided to design and print substitute screws and bolts.

title: Darkwing Duck Gas Gun Display Stand

description.text:
I was a huge Darkwing Duck fan growing up and saw there was a design of the Gas Gun that was created by TJJohn12 here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1605298

I loved finally having one in my hands but needed a way to display it when not battling Negaduck, so I created a display stand to go along with it.

Please keep in mind that I haven't created a 3D model in years, so it's very basic but get's the job done.

The overall model consists of 2 parts which are the main base and the holder piece that holds up the front of the gun. The main base part has holders built into it for the bottom of the handle and the bottom of the front holder. All you need to do is super glue the front holder into the slot of the base.

Both parts can be printed flat.

It was modeled in Fusion 360 and then printed on a CR-10 with 3D Solutech filament at 0.1 resolution. The nozzle temp was 207 degrees. The initial bed temp was 72 degrees while the printing temp was at 65 degrees for the rest of the print.

Enjoy!

A modular, OpenLOCK bridge that can be expanded in a number of ways in the future, but has the pieces to expand it's length now.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

To build a basic, one arch bridge, you will need to print:

  • 2 of bridge_arch.wall.stl or bridge_arch.wall.magnetic.stl
  • 2 of bridge_arch.wall.mirrored.stl or bridge_arch.wall.magnetic.mirrored.stl
  • 2 of bridge_top.wall.stl or bridge_top.wall.magnetic.stl
  • 2 of bridge_top.wall.mirrored.stl or bridge_top.wall.magnetic.mirrored.stl
  • 2 of bridge_ramp.wall.short.stl or bridge_ramp.wall.short.magnetic.stl
  • 2 of bridge_ramp.wall.short.mirrored.stl or bridge_ramp.wall.short.magnetic.mirrored.stl

For each additional arch in the center, print:

  • 2 of bridge_arch.wall.span.stl or bridge_arch.wall.span.magnetic.stl
  • 2 of bridge_top.wall.span.stl or bridge_top.wall.span.magnetic.stl

If using magnets, the magnets are 1/8" x 3/32" disk magnets. You'll need a fair number of them. (9 4) arches, (2 4) tops, (8 4) ramps = 76 for a basic bridge, and another (6 2) arches, (4 * 2) tops = 20 for each additional span. Luckily, those magnets are only $1.40 per 10. You can use openlock, or even use a combination of openlock and magnets. A 1/8" drill bit is handy for clearing out the hole if it's not well cleared (because of say overextrusion). I use both magnets and openlock for different reasons.

Other Sets
  • Paint Guide
  • Bridge Set 1 Basic Bridge, Longer bridges
  • Bridge Set 2 Wider Bridges, Taller Bridges
  • Bridge Set 3 Broken Bridges
  • Bridge Set 4 Narrow Bridges
  • Bridge Set 5 Broken Bridge Updates
  • Bridge Set 6 Flat Arch
  • Bridge Set 7 No Walls

author: acstrobe

description.text:
Based on the awesome work by cadsys, but with a few tweaks and improvements.

The extruder mount is slightly modified to take a wider range of extruders, including the cheap chinese aluminium ones I had on hand. The hot end mount is now one piece as I found it hard to get the clip on fan mounts to sit in the right spot without them sliding around. The hot ends are also easily height adjustable with a single locking screw to slide them up and down. The catch is that the hotend mount now requires support to print, but the original fan mounts did anyway so its not that much of a compromise.

Drill out the holes in the hot end sliders to 2.5mm before tapping them M3. Because they go through the print sideways be super careful with your tap and go slow or the part may split. Try increasing your print temperature by 10 deg when printing the sliders, the extra layer adhesion should make them a bit stronger.

stopsel.stl can be used for that reason. I don't do for me because I want to have accessible adjustment elements, for later. (at my lot of old cars, I'm often angry because I don't know how to open the inside door covers. Then, the plastic holders will break)
If I cut edges and make a cap for gluing, screws are protected forever. Snap-in elements in FDM print are no good experience to me.
My intention is not a very perfect work. It has to run good, I'll want to learn something by making the design. I hope, it is useful to other people. Perfect design is wasted time. Design is in a free license, everybody is invited to continue.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the case in a vertical position with the top and bottom ends on the print bed.  I also oriented the halves along the x-axis to reduce z-axis vibration during the print process.

description.text:
I needed a case for my new LG K20 so I created one from scratch. The model prints as two pieces that I printed in a vertical position and slid on to the top and bottom of the phone. I did not have to scale the print to get it to fit but YMMV.

So this remix has a couple improvements.

  • Thicker back to improve print quality. This modification was somewhat crude ;(
  • Added a bevel to the sides to improve grip.
  • Optional (version 3) added perforations to back to improve grip.

More design improvements:
The bottom opening is much larger than needed.
While lemon shape perforations are easy to print and very functional for gripping the phone, I am not all that enamored with the appearance. So I may redesign again.

Also posting an OBJ file and the AutoDesk 123 Design files in case someone wants to tinker with the design.

The case is decorative and while it may impart some impact protection, there are no implied warranties or guarantees.

description.text: Burj Khalifa

M3 * 8 screw
M3 rod

This is a 3D printer air filter enclosure designed in Openscad. It was designed around the Lowes: Shop-Vac 5-Gallon Cartridge Filter (195mm dia of rubber ring) which has a solid plastic backing on one side and open on the other. This was also designed around a spare 120mm 12v PC fan that I had sitting around. The 12v fan sits in the 3D printed housing and creates a vacuum in a 1 1/4" shop vac hose (also available at Lowes). The bottom ring of the 3D printed housing sits on the rubber sealing ring of the shop vac filter.

NOTE: updated scad program to work with the customizer
NOTE: this design as it is, needs a printer capable of printing a 190mm ring (base of air filter enclosure)

The other end of the vacuum hose attaches to the foam-board enclosure you build around your 3D printer (using the 1 1/4" hose connectors supplied in the 8' Lowes shop-vac hose item).
I have gotten several ABS spools in the past that had really strong chemical odor and released tiny nano-particles. This shop-vac filter device (plus I put a humidifier foam ring over the filter for extra coverage) should stop those particles.

I printed it at 80mm/sec and it claimed 6 hours to print (finished in about 3/4 of that time).

description.text:
Since several people mentioned having trouble printing the original clamp as a single piece - what with the pieces fusing together and all - I decided to separate this into two individual pieces assembled with a nut and bolt. You will need an m3 x 15mm long bolt, a 3mm nut and a couple of 3mm washers, although the washers are optional.

Harley Quinn would be so proud!

FYI - I find that adding a drop of nail polish to the end of the threads of the bolt before and after snugging the nut down will keep the nut from backing off during use. Alternatively, you could also use a nyloc nut.

Research

In my research on the AK family i had to go through a LOT of websites to find out what to do, I've tried to distinguish this from the AK47 as much as i can and people with a keen eye for details and knowledge of AK rifles will see the differences. I decided to do the AKM because it's honestly a lot better than the AK47, although many will call it an AK47 and it retains the same aesthetic, so whadeva. I've got some other gun models I'm working on right now that I'll release in a few weeks, so if you're into little gun models then follow xd
Just scale in the x direction for your desired length.

title: CTC i3 PRO B, X Axis Modified spindle mounts

description.text: Just a remix of original parts, I added an extra Top mount for the spindle nut, the printer is much better using the top mount instead of the bottom, moving pivot point away from motor reduces the wobble by a massive amount. Leave the top ends of the threaded rod floating(no bearings). Check tension on belts, too much tension causes steppers to skip steps. I printed all 3 part in PLA at .2mm, 30mm/s 35 infill, with added supports between top and bottom mounts (ideamaker slicer). Takes hours to print but was well worth it.

This is the mod every Whoop pilot must give a try!...

A so simple thing for so better flight caracteristics...First I didn't believe too much in it, but I have to say my Whoop flies way better with this mod...

There are some carbonfiber versions on sale, but they are heavy and pop easily when you crash.

Printed in ABS or PLA in 0.8mm thikness, it weights almost nothing (just under 0.3 gr) and you definitely don't feel it when you fly, neither your battery...

The first version is designed for 65mm Whoop frame and 6mm motors, fits Inductrix Tiny Whoop and Kingkong Tiny 6-65mm (and maybe other frames but I haven't tested it yet)

The second version is for the Beta Fpv 65s with 7mm motors

By the way, this Kingkong is a fantastic Whoop declination, it flies realy great even with stock motors, witch impressed me quite a bit...

See the video and juge by yourself (Kingkong Tiny 6 65mm all stock)

https://youtu.be/cbQpBYlETM0

You can find this little beast here:

https://www.banggood.com/KINGKONG-TINY6-65mm-Micro-FPV-Quacopter-With-615-Brushed-Motors-Baced-on-F3-Brush-Flight-Controller-p-1134635.html?p=MY23025537272201607R&cur_warehouse=CN

Some better motors:

https://www.banggood.com/4X-Racerstar-615-6x15mm-67000RPM-Coreless-Motor-for-Eachine-E010-E010S-Blade-Inductrix-Tiny-Whoop-p-1141773.html?p=MY23025537272201607R&cur_warehouse=CN

title: Custom Motherboard Cover for Easy3DMaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement part for the Easy3DMaker printer.
The original motherboard cover has flaws:

  • Nearly no air outflow possibility. The back is open but all the cables block the way.
  • The cooling fan is on top causing two problems:
  • When the heated bed is low for a tall print, the fan will suck in heated air.
  • Also if something small falls down at the edge of the bed, just above the fan, it may fall on the motherboard.

This custom case has holes on the side of it where all the motor controllers are. The controllers tend to be pretty hot, and there is a failsafe inside them to shut down a bit if too hot, resulting in layer shifting. (I would also advise to put heatsinks on them)

Also the fan is on the side, preventing from anything to fall inside. And the used air is probably cooler when the bed is low.

Warning: This cover will prevent the (IMHO pretty crappy) rotating filament spool holder at the bottom of the printer.
I advise to use a separate vertical filament spool holder.

I included a model with my custom made support, because I had some problems with automatically generated support.

Printer:

Easy3DMaker - modded

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

Nozzle: 0.5mm

Remove support carefully, because the whole case is thin.

The fan should be inserted after the case is screwed in place.
Because of this it is impossible to put nuts on the fan screws.
I designed the fan screw holes to be just enough small to hold the screws in place, this way acting as nuts.

author: Kde47

print_settings.Notes:: Pretty easy to print, just make sure the side with the nut holes is facing up so there are no overhangs. Make sure infill is set to grid. Using rectilinear means it prints infill in alternating directions every layer, vs grid that does both directions every layer which gives you substantially better internal layer adhesion.I printed mine with 2 perimeters/shells but you could do 3 if you wanted to be safer, though the part is mostly only under the stress of the belt. I printed mine in PLA and I see no need to print it in ABS or any other higher strength plastic.

description.text:
About a year ago, I designed a bracket for the Printrbot Play that utilized the full size of the bed using some longer smooth rods. I recently built another Play but this time with a barebones kit and a bed that was missing its holes. I decided that instead of drilling my own holes and buying a heater PCB, I should try the T15x23 beds made for old Flahsforges.

It fit perfectly (after removing the wire connector, soldering directly is safer anyway) and just needed some brackets to mount them to the rods. This design uses M3 screws and captive nuts. I cut the screws to length and you want about 28 mm for non-countersunk screws, maybe 28-27 for countersunk. You also need to remove the Z motor screw that's closest to the bed. The brackets are tall enough that they should keep the wires for the heated bed out of the way.

This is too large to be printed on the stock Printrbot Play. This is perfect for someone who has a play but finds its build volume a bit too restrictive, so they have another printer that they use most of the time.

BOM:
2x 300 mm smooth rods (look on ebay or aliexpress)
T15x23 bed from RepRap Champion (also available on Amazon)
4x 28 mm m3 screw
4x m3 nuts, preferably lock nuts
GT2 belt (I'd recommend just getting 5 meters if you don't already have some)
Zip ties for the belt and bed wires
Cable sleeving helps a ton for keeping the bed wires out of the way as well as kapton tape for giving the wires more support and taking strain off the solder connections

Printer:

Printrbot Simple

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30% grid

Notes:

Pretty easy to print, just make sure the side with the nut holes is facing up so there are no overhangs. Make sure infill is set to grid. Using rectilinear means it prints infill in alternating directions every layer, vs grid that does both directions every layer which gives you substantially better internal layer adhesion.I printed mine with 2 perimeters/shells but you could do 3 if you wanted to be safer, though the part is mostly only under the stress of the belt. I printed mine in PLA and I see no need to print it in ABS or any other higher strength plastic.

I was kind of lazy with this design and originally designed it for some leftover rods that are 303 mm. This was super easy to design and if you want something better, I implore you to make something better. You can import the STEP file into Fusion 360 and project most of what you need like the rod and belt holes. The Play files are here: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-play-model

title: My MDF Ikea LACK enclosure for ANET A8

description.text:
UPDATED January 31/2017: It seems that there was some problem with the STL of the upper parts.
.- Repaired and uploaded upper parts.
.- Added the magnet and the door plate.
.- As moving the top was very heavy, I put some latches on the sides.

As in a big city like Barcelona, living in an apartment is the usual thing, I needed an enclosure that would reduce the noise, and since I am preferably working on ABS, I would keep the heat.
Looking for solutions, I found the Ikea LACK enclosures. Unfortunately, all are oriented to transparent plastic plates, which are especially expensive, at least in Barcelona.
They also did not convince me as noise insulators, so I decided to use MDF plates, cheaper and easier to find.

I paid particular attention to the solution provided by OmNomNomagon, so I contacted him, in case he had time to make some changes, but at full Christmas, it could not be.

Heartfelt thanks, mate, if you read this.

So I decided to start designing my own pieces from scratch, using their inspiration as their own.

The size of the bases is 20 mm, and that of the extensions of 80mm, with which we raise the table 10cm.

The material, I got it at Leroy Merlin, that you can cut for free the MDF to measure. The one that I have used is:
Tablero MDF, Two boards of 120x60X1.9, cut to 50x44.5, 3 pieces, (with the remainder, I requested a cut of 55x55, for future use).

For the door, I used the so-called Plastic Glass, made of polystyrene, which is very cheap, and easy to cut with a cutter, which I have used is:
Vidrio Plástico, a board of 1x0.5 m x 2.5 mm, which I cut to 50x44.5.

The MDF boards are placed from the outside and screwed in from inside the legs and the upper clamping pieces, thus allowing to completely remove the assembly, leaving the printer exposed, to be able to operate it from all directions.

Although it was not necessary, he had planned to put a small neodymium magnet on the top right to ensure the door was closed.

To avoid vibration, and reduce the noise of the printer, I have placed a cut-off plate of CA-150, which I already had, of the insulation of the blinds of my flat.

Anyway, in Leroy Merlin, it is available: Panel de aislamiento acústico COPOPREN T CA-150 1000X1000X20MM.

** WARNING, the space that remains, between the right and left sides and the printer, is very small. It works for me, but maybe it's not what you expect.

With a small handle, some hinges, and a filament guide like this: Filament Guide Ikea Lack Table,I completed the enclosure.

If you need anything else, let me know.

Anet A8

0,2

Infill:

20%

title: Greg's Wade Bowden extruder Creality Ender 2 / CR 10

description.text:
Video: https://www.youtube.com/edit?o=U&video_id=tfDMYGnhWY4
This is Greg's Wade extruder adapted for the Ender 2, probably also fits the CR 10 (not tested). With the extruder the Ender prints much better and you can relieve the stepper driver without step losses. My Nema 17 engine is only lukewarm, previously very hot. The esteps must be adjusted, with the original firmware can not save, must be entered at each reboot. That's why I flashed my Ender on Marlin. that is relatively easy, instructions are available online.

Have fun with it

(Original Description:

Adapted for E3D Hobb Goblin 8mm hobbed shaft
Adapted for PC4-M5 bowden connector

Filament path is extended to provide contact with Hobb Goblin 8mm hobbed shaft and 608ZZ skate bearing. This extended path should allow for flexible filaments without the potential for kinking material.

Assembly instructions / Bill of Material : http://reprap.org/wiki/Wade's_Geared_Extruder )

author: claytonbakerjr

title: Squash Ball Anti Vibration Mount For 3D Printer (CR-10/CR-10S)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are anti vibration mounts designed to hold a squash ball to be used as the feet on a 3D printer. There are multiple versions of the mount suited to different extrusions (2020 or 2040) in both M4 and M5 hardware. You will need 4 x double yellow dot squash balls and appropriate hardware (you will be able to re-use the hardware on the CR-10/CR-10S from the existing feet).

Versions explained...

  • Anti Vibration Mount M4 - designed for 2040 extrusion
  • Anti Vibration Mount M4 (2020) - designed for 2020 extrusion
  • Anti Vibration Mount M4 Multi - designed to mount to either 2020 or 2040 extrusions
  • Anti Vibration Mount M5 - designed for 2040 extrusion
  • Anti Vibration Mount M5 (2020) - designed for 2020 extrusion
  • Anti Vibration Mount M5 Multi - designed to mount to either 2020 or 2040 extrusions

Printer:

CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%-100%

comments.text: Wanted to add a note here for others who have a CR-10 like mine that have two holes on one side and one on the other. The multi mounts with 3 holes on each side will work fine for your printer. I used the 4mm multi mount for my CR-10 and this printed fine.

comments.text: The CR-10S has either 2020 (front and rear) or 2040 (left and right sides) and they are referred to by their measurement. The 2020 extrusion is 20mm x 20mm, 2040 is 20mm x 40mm.  I assume all CR-10S are the same and mine came with M4 screws and drop-in T-nuts on the original feet and to use these anti vibration feet in the same location as the original feet you will need to print 4 x Anti_Vibration_Mount_M4.stl

title: Anemone Display Tentacle (NodeMCU v2 Display Case)

description.text:
Anemone Display Tentacle is a 3D printable case for NodeMCU v2 and 128x64 OLED i2c Display.

It is part of the open and free #anemoneCloud Platform, but it can be used completely standalone as well.

When used inside the Anemone Platform the Tentacle could be used as a DYI Open Hardware device which can be easily connected to cloud APIs, mobile app and/or other tentacles of open hardware devices. All this completely free of any charge. More documentation about how to use this Tentacle in the Anemone Ecosystem can be found at: Anemone Docs.

When used outside the Anemone Platform it can be used as a cute case for your NodeMCU v2 and 128x64 OLED i2c Display

You will need the following to assemble Display Tentacle

  • 1x NodeMCU v2 CP2102 (costs 3 USD only!)
  • 1x 128x64 OLED i2c Display
  • 1x Breadboard SYB-170
  • 4x Male to Female 10cm Jumper Cable
  • 1x USB-A to micro-USB cable

I am not the sole author of this thing or of the Anemone Project. Anemone Tentacle has been created as a team effort of our great team at Juicymo and our client. See more info about who is behind this here.

Tentacle Visualization can be found at YouTube

#anemoneCloud

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

ABS 0.35mm (first layer 0.15mm)

Infill:

20% Cubic

Notes:

The Anemone Tentacle 3D case is available either as .stl files of 3 individual components:

  • The Bottom Part (Anemone_Display_Tentacle_Bottom.stl)
  • The Case (Anemone_Display_Tentacle_Case.stl)
  • The Top (Anemone_Display_Tentacle_Top.stl)

Or as a ready-to-print .stl file with all components (to be printed all at once):

  • Anemone_Display_Tentacle.stl

In addition to the .stl ready-to-print file you can download a exported gcode file for the Prusa i3 MK2S 3D Printer with ABS filament setting - ABS_ANEMONE_DISPLAY.gcode. We have used this gcode file to print our version of Anemone Button Tentacle on Kanárek (Prusa i3 MK2S Original 3D Printer).

Recommended print settings

The Anemone Tentacle case is optimized to be printed in ABS (but we have tested printing with PLA too and it works well).

We have used the open source Prusa Slic3r for slicing the .stl files into .gcode. The Prusa Slic3r has few advantages compared to the original Slic3r (like better supports and more).

Anemone Tentacle case looks awesome even on low print settings - which looks nice with a semi-transparent filament.

Global settings

  • Filament: ABS 1.75mm
  • Extruder Temperature: 255°C
  • Heat-bed Temperature: 100°C
  • Layer height: 0.35mm
  • First layer height: 0.15mm
  • Perimeters: 1
  • Infill density: 20%
  • Infill pattern: Cubic
  • Skirt: 1
  • Brim: 4mm
  • Support: Yes

Tips and Tricks

  • When printing with ABS you HAVE TO to use the heated bed!

After printing the second part (The Case) needs to be cleaned of supports.

When done you can assemble the Anemone Display Tentacle case.

The Anemone IoT Platform Story

The original idea for Anemone was to create a simple Open Hardware device which would be able to send information to the cloud (or internet) and which will be very easy to use for others.

Over time, the idea expanded a little. And we have ended up creating not just the Open Hardware device itself (we call it a Tentacle) but 3D printable case, cloud web application and even mobile application for iOS and Android as well.

And now we in fact have quite a nice ecosystem. Not with many apps right now, but it is ready to use! And that is where we need your help ;)

With Anemone, you can create a cloud enabled IoT apps in a very easy way and get them hosted for free in the Anemone Cloud. Or you can just print the Tentacle Case and upload a picture of it to the I made it section. Our Anemone Display Tentacle case is the very first 3D printed case for the NodeMCU v2 and SSD1306 128x64 OLED i2c Display.

And you can use it freely even completely outside the Anemone platform too.

So enjoy! ;)

I am not the sole author of this thing or of the Anemone Project. Anemone Tentacle has been created as a team effort of our great team at Juicymo and our client. See more info about who is behind this here.
CCSS
This lesson can be used as a semestral work for any subject featuring electronics, programming and 3D printing.

In this project you will learn how to assemble and program a working open hardware device with a cute 3D Printed case.

The Tentacle can be used as part of the open and free Anemone Platform, or completely standalone. The project plan is divided accordingly.

• Preparation - Put all required components together
  • 3D Print a Tentacle case
  • Assemble your Tentacle

• Understand how Anemone Platform works
  • Understand different types of Anemone Tentacles
  • Connect your Tentacle to the Anemone Cloud
  • Understand how the Flow and Flow Editor works

• Read the NodeMCU v2 on Arduino documentation
  • Program your NodeMCU v2 as you see fit ;)

The following components are needed for your Display Tentacle: 1x NodeMCU v2 CP2102 (costs 3 USD only!)
1x 128x64 OLED i2c Display
1x Breadboard SYB-170
4x Male to Female 10cm Jumper Cable
1x USB-A to micro-USB cable

• 3D Printing
  • Electronics
  • Programming
3D Printing Setup: 30min + 3D Printing: 3h + Programming: 30min = 4h

• You need to have all the required components
  • You should 3D print a case
  • You should assemble the case
    • And you are ready for connecting your Tentacle to Anemone Ecosystem.

Anemone Display Tentacle can be used in a tasks like "Creation of a cloud enabled Open Hardware Device". An example assessment for students could be:

Your task is to create a working Anemone Display Tentacle open hardware device. Your task is the following:

  1. 3D print a Tentacle case
  2. Assemble the Tentacle electronics (see the Materials Needed section)
  3. Program the device (a detailed instructions are available when you will create a new Tentacle in the Anemone Platform - you can sign in for free)
The student assessment is a success when:
  • Students were able to construct a working Anemone Display Tentacle device and they were able to communicate with a Anemone Cloud Flow.

    • Students should work in teams of two.

• The Anemone IoT Platform www.anemone.cloud
  • Anemone Platform Documentation docs.anemone.cloud
  • Anemone Example Flows
  • All supported Anemone Tentacles
  • The authors WebAPI Team & Juicymo

    • The "sister" Anemone Button Tentacle case

author: emimobilebox

description.text: Here is another leveling thumb knob for the Peopoly Moai. The knob has 7 numbers and is for a 4mm x .7mm pitch nut so each number is .100mm increment when turned. I haven't needed to use it on my machine yet but it does fit on a nut.

The sculpture consists of five sub-tracks which gives approximately 15 meters of rail made of 3mm brass rod, a total of 106 3D-Printed pieces is in the sculpture. Estimated time for the design in Google SketchUp was approximately 150 hours.

The construction has taken place during the two years when I had time to spare. Everything is manual bent, welded and adjusted in to the smallest detail.

Estimated construction time in total was approximately 250 hours.

Movie: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k8BOKpcJi2Y

This is an Interactive sculpture, you push the button and the robot arm picks up the ball and put it on a randomly selected track and returns to "home" then when the ball has come to the end of the track you can push the button again and so on... It’s all controlled via a Pololu Mini Maestro 12-Channel USB Servo Controller (https://www.pololu.com/product/1352)

To be able to get the randomness for the track selection (there is no random functionality in the Mini Maestro programming language) I had to use the analog sensors that “sees” the ball on the track ends at the pickup position. Because of the balls surface, the sensor will give different values depending on how the ball is positioned. This value is then used to calculate on what track to put the ball next.

The robot is heavily influenced of the EEZYbotArm (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015238).

You can find the program I use in the program zip file.

This sculpture was actually done already in 2016. I just forgot to publish it.
If you have any questions, just let me know. I'll do my best to answer. :)

Enjoy.

Made this side for the Peon230. It'll help keep components safe inside and keep dirt out. I put GPS mounts to the side and they'll accept the common 4mm rod that comes with HolyBro (and a few others) GPS systems. There are vents in the side to help keep your stack cool. I have found that if the GPS mounting holes are a little snug just hit em with a drill bit quick to clean them up a little. I have mounted these to both 3D printed and standard nylon standoffs. To make both sides just simply mirror the image in you 3D slicer. Made for the 40mm length standoff.

description.text: Trying to understand Openscad 3d design capabilities I decided to work on something practical, a clip bag, even if I found tons on thingiverse it's a simple project but with some design difficulties for beginners like me. For example, I used small gaps in joint parts in order to avoid usage of support during 3d print. Everything is parametric so it's possible to alter size, radius of the thing and add a carved text as well. I quite satisfied with the result and I decided to share it to the community. It prints good in PLA with a >30% infill in order to make it solid enough. Every suggestion on how to improve the code is very welcome. Hope you like, and good 3d printing!

title: 65mm CNC Spindle Mounts for C-Beam Extrusion

description.text:
These mounts are keyed to fit OpenBuilds type c-beam extrusions ensuring a secure and perfectly aligned 65mm diameter spindle. The design also includes two 11mm through holes on each mount to allow clean routing of air blower and cutting fluid lines.

These are perfect for the MiniMill, C-Beam, C-beam XL or any other cnc where the spindle mounts to a c-beam 4080 size v-slot extrusion.

Required Fasteners (sourced either on Amazon http://amzn.to/2maFdec or from your local supplier)

  • 4 x M5 15mm low profile or button head screws
  • 4 x M5 t-nuts
  • 4 x M5 30mm low profile or button head screws (25mm will just work too)
  • 4 x M5 nuts

title: Retron 5 Controller Holder for NES and SNES

description.text:
As we all know, the Retron 5 controller is an abomination. The 8bitdo wireless controllers are excellent alternatives, but don't sit nicely in the controller slot in the back. I did my best to match the styling of the Retron, while also making sure that there was adequate venting for the electronics.

While this was designed with the 8bitdo controllers, I expect it should work for original NES/SNES controllers, possibly with clips to keep the cables from pulling them over.

title: Airsoft motion sensor claymore mine MKII
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
--- Free commercial use, unwatermarked files, full electric diagram, link to the products, tweaks, settings and arduino program are on sale for 10 Euros via paypal, if you're interested write me a message, you will just have to basically assemble the object and load my program ---

--- components price tag approx. 10 Euros ---

Here is the first final version of the motion sensor mine. Range of detection and firing is 3-6 meters (depending on how strong are your springs). No need to have a mechanical trigger or waiting to press the button to fire the mine: everything is fully automatic. Just place and it is done!
The original program also includes a buzzer (to have an acoustic feedback of the explosion). Built-in delay on the sketch grants optimal calibration for the passive infrared sensor: no misfires at all.
The project will be updated in the future.

Obviously if you have knowledge of arduino and electronic components you can do everything by your own.

PLEASE NOTE: no commercial use unless you purchase full license!

author: rackley

title: Tatara Z axis Linear guide upgrade for A8 V1.00

description.text:
This is the pieces you need to upgrade the Tatara A8 Steel V1.00 with linear guides on Z axis

Many of you ask if is possible to upgrade the V1.00 TATARA A8 Steel to be used with mini linear guide, the answer is yes.
But personally we think is too much hassle, than do it at your own risk.

You have 2 way to do this:
For boot solutions you need laser cuts the new parts:
2 x ZMT11-DE
2 x ZMS11
2 x TP11-DE (optional but suggested)

1-Do a new cut of the XZ frame CODE: XZ10-SI15 who have the holes for the linear guide at each side and remove some useless holes

or

2- 3D print a "Holes template" for the original XZ frame V1.00 and drill you self, holes diameter size must be 3.2mm.
You have to start with the low holes (the round corner go UP) The bottom of the printed hole template must touch the ZMT11-DE the hole are at 10mm form the outer edge. Once you drill the 5th hole you move the guide and you block with one screw on the 5th hole and you drill the other 4 holes. Print the hole template for other side or reuse it if is not damaged.
The holes on hole template are 2.2mm if you want pre drill with smaller drill bit.

Both this solution can use the custom carriage we design (PP-CXZ-R-SI15-DE, PP-CXZ-L-SI15-DE).(ready soon)
If you don't want re cut the ZTM and ZMS parts we don't know how linear guide will perform at that distance from lead screw and the custom carriage will not work.

Same mini linear guide as V1.1 HAYABUSA will be used:
Kit: TKE-04-015-1-352 (you need 2, one for each side: 1 fix and 1 floating LLZ)

FAQ:
Why if i drill vs cut the XZ10-SI15 part the holes heigth are differents: That's normal because in old version has the guide for Z end stop and we can't drill on the edges of it.

Like always refer to Official Tatara Steel Frame Owner Group for questions:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/TataraFrameOwnerGroupOfficial

author: TataraTeam

title: Old design for Micro-Swiss hotend See Notes

description.text:
UPDATE 1/26/2018

I AM NO LONGER SUPPORTING THIS FANG AS I HAVE DESIGNED A MUCH BETTER DUCT SYSTEM. SEE INFO BELOW.

I was having issues with the airflow direction from this fang. It was pointing more down into the print than I would like causing extra long (200mm) bridging to sag. I got some help from a Commercial HVAC Engineer and developed the new duct I am currently using which directs the air horizontal .5mm from the tip and allows me to bridge 200mm easily.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2759439

title: Nerf Titan Barrel Adapter for 1/2" conduit

description.text:
This is a very simple adaptation of RhinoAus' Titan barrel adapter. I've changed the size of the hole such that it should work with 1/2" conduit, which has an actual OD of 0.840 inches.

Potentially confusingly, this conduit is sometimes referred to as 16mm - but 16mm is the nominal ID and therefore RhinoAus' 16mm adapter is not suitable.

title: Counter weight for Feiyu G5 gimbal

description.text:
This is counter weight for Feiyu G5 gimbal with Garmin Virb 30 + its waterproof housing.

The weight of virb 30 is ~85g, and the weight of housing is ~75g.

This counter weight is around 80~100g (depends on your material, 100g if using copper) to compensate the extra 75g took by housing.

Note!! do not print this counter weight, use metal and Milling machine!

description.text: This is a triple 40mm fan duct for E3D V6 style hot-ends. It is designed to snap around the V6 heat sink and has provisions for a 30mm long M3 screw, nut and washers for extra clamping. The center fan can be either 10mm or 20mm thick if extra cooling is needed.

Home Brew

No

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

25%

How I did it.

The model was drawn in Sketchup at a 1000:1 scale. I used Curviloft to create the fun shapes. Using a 1000:1 scale helps Sketchup calculate surface intersections better, and exporting STL files in meters creates perfect mm scale STL files.

The Sketchup file can be found in the Sketchup Warehouse at

https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/4701392f-d324-407e-9252-9bb6a715f83a/Knock-off-Titan-Extruder-With-40mm-fan-blower

title: Spinolution bobbin for Echo and Mach III

description.text:
This spinning wheel bobbin was designed for the SpinOlution spinning wheel. This is an easy print. You will need to turn on supports to get a good print. The project comes out fairly clean, with only a little cleanup on the supports.

For the Echo use Bobbin1.stl and Bobbin2.stl. For the Mach III use Mach3bobbin1.stl and Mach3bobbin2.stl. Both bobbins are assembled the same way.

To turn this into a complete bobbin for your echo, you will need to get a small M8 washer, and a piece of 1/2" PEX, CPVC, or copper pipe. I'm including links

https://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-M8-Zinc-Plated-Flat-Washer-4-Pack-803558/204276431

https://www.homedepot.com/p/SharkBite-1-2-in-x-2-ft-White-PEX-Pipe-U860W2/205047980

After printing the BobbinEnd1 file, insert the washer into the round end. Then insert the pex tube into the hole on top of the washer. Press down on it hard to get the washer all the way seated. It's a tight fit, but it is possible. Pull the pex tube out and glue it. I just use plain old super glue with mine.

Measure and cut the tube so that the height is the same as your existing the bobbin. If you don't already have a pipe cutter, I highly recommend getting one. You can complete this project without one, but it sure makes it easier.

I use this one:
https://www.homedepot.com/p/HDX-Junior-Tube-Cutter-HDX003/204218579

Once you have press fitted the top piece, test it to make sure it will fit your spinning wheel. When you feel good about everything, glue the top piece to the tube.

If you find this useful, please let me know in the comments.

La correa fue realizada en Nylon 12 de Grillon, excelente material , es mas tenso que el Nylon 6 de la misma marca aunque creo que es totalmente posible hacerlas en Flex, Nylon 6 o Nylon 12, el tema de las correas es que las impresas no tienen el cinturon o backPlain, que es la tela o hilos posteriores que le dan la rigides y los dientes el timing.
Cambie las libretiras de SCAD de corread para que ahora pueda tenes unas canaletas por donde se pueda pasar un hilo de poliester multifilamento ( como las correas comunes ) o tanza de acero de pesca.
Una vez pasado el material se completa con una capa de suprabond transparente, o silicona, para asegurar cualquier desprendimiento

description.text:
This is a very rough mockup of the cyclops clone pictured, it's not an exact replica but the external dimensions and the positions of the mounting holes are correct. This should be enough to let anyone test out their x carriage designs for fit. I didn't add the mounting holes for the fan as they are for a 30mm fan and I'm using a 40mm.

I have one of these clones ordered but it's coming from China and won't be here for another couple of weeks so I made this to let me get on with building my x-carriage while waiting for it to arrive. When it's all fitted and working I'll post it.

These clones are very different to the E3D originals and to the "lookalike" clones especially the mounting holes.

title: Primus Suck On This
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
All Primus fans will recognize this! A sculpture by artist Lance Montoya for Primus' album "Suck On This." I never got around to sculpting this in clay, but I happened to create it in 3dMax, and now I can share it with others.
I printed one in both PLA and ABS (one pictured is ABS, smoothed using a little acetone brushed on before painting). I then painted using cheap acrylics and a matte varnish to protect it.
Please feel free to ask questions, post comments or critiques.

** This is NOT for commercial use. Last year I had a custom .stl downloaded from Thingiverse and sold online, please don't do that cuz karma is a bitch. (this makes modelers NOT want to model and share more).
